social_posts.post_text:
👩🏽‍🍳 “Regular” dinner nights still often involve work projects for me, like this flashback to a day in October. Four recipe videos to shoot, a branded campaign deadline, and a broccoli-eating zombie to take out for Halloween. Some of the ways I get through the week include:
🍝 Choosing recipes that work double duty as #mealprep, like freezing extra lamb meatballs for a future dinner. 
🍝 Remixing leftover ingredients so we don’t get bored, like meatball subs for day 2 and a roasted chicken parm wrap on day 3.
🍝 Balancing more involved main dishes (or homemade pasta 🤪) with simple veggies, like sheet pan roasted broccoli tossed with parm and lemon.
🍝 Smart ingredient short cuts that help to eliminate some prep, like using garlic cooking oil or doctoring jarred marinara with pantry ingredients. 
🍝 Being strategic with my stovetop and oven, so that there is a flow and synchronicity with the order things are prepared.

Recipes from October’s journals were posted to Patreon for all tiers! November was mostly holiday journaling, and in December I’m diving back into meal prepping for a couple weeks before we resume the holiday shenanigans. Looking forward to sharing more of my work and ideas this way because learning how to cook involves a lot more than following a recipe! 

FAQ: 
📝 it’s the @goodnotes.app  w/ @apple iPad Pro. 
📝 pot by @greatjones 
📝 pasta extruder attachment linked in my stories
📝 heavy duty sheet pans linked in my stories
📝 music playlists linked in my stories (of course #6lack made my top 5. 🔥)

☀️ Hello and happy Sunday! ☀️ It has been awhile since I introduced myself around here. I’m Angela Davis, and I’m a mom of two living in Michigan. I founded #kitchenistadiaries in 2012 to explore my passion for home cooking. I’ve since self-published four cookbooks and worked as a recipe developer and private chef. I retired the original food blog in 2021 to focus on video content creation and launched my Patreon, where you can support my current work and access recipes.

More about me:

☀️ Prior to this career, I was in the construction industry as a senior project accountant. Before that, I was a restaurant server and worked retail selling makeup and waxing brows.
☀️ Grew up as an army brat and never lost the itch to change my surroundings frequently. I consider Northern Virginia to be home. My birthplace is El Paso, TX. I’ve also lived in Florida and Germany.
☀️ My daughter Raven is 8 and my son Jaden is 19. He is living in VA and works as a sous chef! 
☀️ Food and music bring out my inner artist. As a kid I loved to draw and paint. I was classically trained in piano and played until end of high school. My “inner child” therapy work is returning me back to some of those things lately.
☀️ I’m a SA survivor and have battled addiction and ptsd as a result. I was diagnosed with Bipolar 2 at the age of 25. My time in the kitchen has always been a place to heal and the older I get, I am more intentional about that.
☀️ I am blissfully and peacefully single, celibate (4 years) and still terrified of messing that up so there is no word on when y’all will ever get date night recipes. Ask somebody else to do it. 😂
☀️ My favorite things to make include fresh pasta, biscuits, pies, smoked ribs, chicken stews, anything involving duck, and every kind of taco imaginable.
☀️ My favorite veggies include collards, kale, okra, squash, sweet potato, cabbage, and eggplant.
☀️ You’ll never catch me eating black licorice. (But I love fennel.) 
☀️ Sundays are my favorite days to cook so that is where I’m off to now!
☀️ Patreon.com/kitchenista for recipes & shopkitchenista.com for merch and cookbooks.

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenistasundays

Grocery shopping for the week at 168 Asian Mart. Filled up my cart with ingredients for soup and meal prepping.  My goal this week is to get back to that routine I established before Thanksgiving, reset my fridge/freezer for organization, and finish dining room DIY projects.

What are you planning to conquer in the kitchen this week? 💪🏾

🎥 : Chinese eggplant, shiitake mushrooms, bok choy, gynura (longevity spinach), rice vinegar, apple vinegar, fried shallots, curry pastes, bean vermicelli, halibut, beef shank scraps, burro bananas, green papaya, jackfruit, Japanese sweet potatoes and purple sweet potatoes, manioc (yucca)

 #kitchenista #kitchenistadiaries #kitchenistasundays #groceryshopping

💪🏾 Sofrito prep for my soup + a little freezer stash for future dates with @thesofritoproject’s recipes. This is pretty close to her “simple sofrito” on the blog and she has another in her holiday cookbook. My proportions are based on nothing other than this is exactly what was in the fridge lol. Also used her spices to season the sofrito which you can cop from @spicetribe.
🫑🧅🧄
The value in prep is the time to myself and a shift in focus. For 5 minutes, or 20, or however long I decide my therapy session is for the day, all I will worry about is what is in front of me on the cutting board. The monotony and repetition tricks my brain into paying attention to something else. Rituals calm my energy. It’s taking the time to clear my space, fill my oil bottles up, grind black peppercorns, and sharpen the knives. My cooking sessions are not always this laid back and orderly, but I try to squeeze at least a couple appointments with myself in during the week. Sunday is my favorite day to do that, before the anxieties of the new work week set in. When I don’t need to cook a big spread, I use the evening to get a jump start on Monday’s meal prep.
🫑🧄🧅
Also, even if you don’t cook… I just wanted to share a beautiful song with you (Tems - Free Mind) because it was on repeat all weekend. My kitchen playlists are on Apple/Spotify. 

PS. It’s the #Breville 3-cup chopping bowl. I tend to not want to drag out a huge food processor so I don’t mind breaking things up into small batches. This is a convenient kit that comes with the immersion (stick) blender, chopper bowl, and a hand mixer attachment. Covers all the recipe tasks that don’t require heavy artillery. Linked in stories!

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista #kitchenistasundays
Breakfast. 🥚🥑 Texas toast / avocado / lemon / @baobabfare Pili hot sauce / 6-min soft-boiled egg / furikake. #kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista #avocadotoast

🍓🍰 Just stay in and make the lemon buttermilk olive oil cake. It’s way better than anything out there. 😂💅🏽 

Other things you should do
*find my kitchen r&b playlist on Spotify 
*grab the olive oil cake recipe (and other variations) at Patreon.com/kitchenista
*bake as directed but pour the full batch into a prepared Bundt pan instead of 2 loaf pans
*try the cake with lemon curd

or 

*make the balsamic macerated strawberries from my Vol.1 ebook and use white balsamic
*smoke the strawberries for 30 min if you have access to a grill/smoker
*grill slices of olive oil cake
*use heavy whipping cream as it was intended

and 

*eat cake, be happy, and only share with someone who deserves to be there.

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista #oliveoilcake

I’m a big believer in pasta projects for times when I need a challenge to take my mind off other things. The longer and more complicated the better, so figuring out nerdy things like how to cut and shape #pacherripasta was up there in my top 2022 marathons. The cooked pasta was tossed with a spicy braised rabbit ragu, which is appropriate because slow-cooking is also top tier kitchen therapy. I’m going through my yearly highlights and pasta is what jumps out more than anything else in the shoots where I was happiest with my work. I plan to keep embracing more of what I love in 2023. 🔥 

(🎁 Merch available at shopkitchenista.com!) 

#kitchenistadiaries #pastaprojects #freshpasta #kitchenista

2022 highlights! It’s been a year full of camera time and recipe development and kitchen organization. I celebrated ten years of #kitchenistadiaries. Cooked with my best friends (hi @thesofritoproject ❤️) and faced my catered event anxiety head-on. Made a lot of pasta. Ate a lot of pasta. Enjoyed going home to see my family. Traveled. Smoked all of the things. Settled into my new home. Launched merch. Shared new recipes with a new community over on Patreon. Embraced digital journaling. Established new routines.

Rebuilt.

2021 uprooted me in necessary ways. I needed a bigger pot and different soil to grow. (Word to @donyetaylor.) In 2022, I was a lot more intentional about choosing to fall in love with a new kitchen, to fall in love with food and cooking in ways that would re-energize this journey. I invested in my own goals and spent time with myself in productive ways. Explored a lot of self-therapy that is helping me peel back more of the layers. This has been a healing journey. I decided not to let past traumas win. They don’t get to hold me back or make me want to dim my light anymore. I’m willing to do the work do rid myself of dead weight, of the masks, of the old habits from when I was simply trying to survive. I’m spending the rest of my year setting 2023 intentions, because I know that I want more of this. I’m ready to thrive. 

💐💐 I have lots of thank you’s to get out this year, but this one is for Jean Grae who deserves all of the flowers so I’d like to do that before she moves on from her current IG account. (But you can and *should* go support via Patreon!) Thank you @jeanniegrigio, for modeling what it looks like to stand in your truth, be different,  experiment with art, to be vulnerable and giving while demanding respect in spaces that don’t always appreciate it, and for showing us that there is freedom in reinventing yourself as often as possible. ❤️💐💐

#kitchenistasundays #kitchenista

Spicy 🦀 puttanesca recipe is over on patreon, for the adventurous palates. I used up some smoked tomatoes and crab claw meat, but this is otherwise a recipe that can be achieved from humble pantry ingredients. If you don’t like olives or capers or anchovies then puttanesca is not for you, just make marinara. What’s understood does not need to be explained. 😉

Sometimes I just like to edit a reel to a song I wanted to share, for a moment. Music is second to food in things that overwhelm me with emotions, and this is the kind of song that I want to live inside if that makes sense. There are so many different parts that it’s hard to pick the perfect 90 seconds. Tangle by The Hics.  If you listen to it feel free to let me know your thoughts. ❤️

Wishing everyone a week as fantastic as the word “puttanesca.”

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenistasundays

Smoked pork spare ribs & burnt honey agrodolce. Recipe notes were posted to Patreon earlier this year. 

“Recipes for people who are going through some shit” should be a genre and it is one of my specialties. Even when it’s below freezing, don’t count out the therapeutic value in taking out your feelings on a slab of meat that takes 6 hours to cook. Plenty of time to get some sun, cry, write, make a sauce, cook some veggies, have a drink. Then you get to sit down and eat delicious food. You cannot pay for a better therapy session, just saying. 

#kitchenistadiaries

Jerk smoked duck, finished in banana leaves. Curry tortillas, coconut rice, green mango slaw, papaya hot sauce, curried chickpeas. Jan/Feb 2022. #kitchenistadiaries 

I’m a dope home cook & my ability to translate that into content is fucking brilliant. I need to get comfortable saying that because I believe it, but saying it is quite another thing in spaces that are designed to humble me. The things that I’m good at doing have often made others uncomfortable, but I am taking notes from folks I admire who have gotten comfortable with not caring. I’m surrounded by other creatives and entrepreneurs who put themselves out there and it inspires me to do more, to keep getting better and reach the places I visualize myself in.

2022 was spent entirely in my own kitchen, supporting myself with my own projects and no employer or full-time clients for the first time in my life. I made a lot of amazing things this year and I learned how to capture that on video. I got over my fear of showing my steps, and sharing my face, and what my hands look like on screen. I pushed past a lot of negativity from people who quite literally told me to unalive myself, that I could never do this, that my phone and I in my kitchen aren’t enough. People who didn’t understand my vision. On any given day my brain is operating a thousand times faster than the thoughts I actually want to articulate and share. There is a lot I need to figure out with discipline and balance and business. But every year I get a little closer, a little better at putting all the puzzle pieces together to figure out what my power is and how to use it to heal myself, and how to use that same power in this medium to say the things I eventually want to say. To create in bigger and more impactful ways. There are aspects of this journey that still feel like free falling and the older I get and more settled I want to be, that can be terrifying. But then there are moments when it seems like the universe is working overtime to show me that I am on the right path, and from there my faith and courage kicks in.

It’s just the duck tacos I had in February. Or, it’s your sign to keep going. ❤️
Walnut banana bread & 90 seconds of calm. Recipe in my Volume 1 cookbook (subbed walnut oil for extra virgin olive oil.) #kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista #burrobananas #bananabread

🌶️ Step up your appetizer game this holiday eating season. Recipe notes for duck fat fried chicken wings are over on Patreon. With the confit method, the brined wings are submerged in duck fat and cooked slowly at a low temp. In the second fry they are at a higher temp to crisp the skin. Results in meltingly tender meat with perfectly crispy skin. 

🌶️ Toss in your favorite sauce after the second fry. My go-to wing sauce is taming a bold hot sauce with honey and butter. Piri piri peppers will definitely catch you slipping, iykyk. 😂

🌶️ Quick dip. Mixed equal parts bleu cheese, mayo, and sour cream, then adjusted amounts for flavor and consistency. Seasoned w/ splash of Worcestershire, lemon juice, black pepper, and chives.

Tag the person who should make these for you. 😁

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenistaholidays #kitchenista #duckfatganggang

🍝🎶 Semolina fried fish & spaghetti w/ spicy lobster marinara, Italian chopped salad. Recipe for the sauce is over on Patreon + throwback r&b playlist linked in my stories. When’s your next date night in the kitchen with you?  #kitchenistadiaries

Smoked duck ramen. 🦆🍜 #kitchenistadiaries 

Used up the last of my thanksgiving duck stock, smoked duck necks, duck feet, chicken bones. Adapted recipes by @ladyandpups in her cookbook, The Art of Escapism Cookbook. Highly recommended if you like challenging kitchen projects and doing crazy shit like obliterating duck bones into bone broth with an immersion blender. GET ALL THOSE FEELINGS OUT. 💪🏾

I have been in love with this Sleater Kinney song, Jumpers, since my 20’s. When I finally made it to the San Francisco bridge ten years later, my brain was 🤯 from all the feels as I reflected on my own dark times. This ramen tastes like everything the song captures, the things we’re afraid to think about. It reminds me of this time of year, and how the coldness seeps into my bones in the mornings as a warning of what’s to come. It is the juxtaposition of comfort and celebration with profound loneliness and grief. I order ramen when I can’t cook for myself, because it’s the closest thing to tasting like someone cared enough to make you real food.

I got the bowls because they make me happy and I’m doing more of that these days. Cherry blossom tats adorn my skin the same way the trees line our driveway back home in Virginia. A reminder that spring always comes, even after the coldest of winters. 

Keep going. 🌸

Stewed okra & shrimp, cooked from freezer and pantry ingredients. Recipe below! Easy and highly adaptable. 💪🏾 #kitchenistadiaries 

🦐
in small bowl:
 1 lb peeled/deveined large shrimp, brined in water + 1 tsp salt + 1/2 tsp baking soda, 15 min
(drain & discard used brine)

🔥
into large skillet, med heat:
2 tbsp palm oil, more as needed
sliced scallion whites
1/2 cup sofrito (or epis, green seasoning)
2 tbsp tomato paste
1 tsp curry powder
1 tsp smoked paprika
salt & pepper to taste
2 bags frozen okra (I added second bag later for mixed textures)
1 cup stock (lobster, seafood, shrimp, chicken, veggie)
1 can full-fat coconut milk
sliced chile peppers, to taste (or hot sauce)

🥣
stir as each ingredient is added.
simmer until sauce is thickened and okra cooked to desired consistency.
adjust seasoning to taste.
reduce heat to low.
stir in shrimp, poach gently until cooked, 2 - 3 min.
finish with lime juice and sliced scallion greens.
served over rice.

subs:
📝 if you don’t have sofrito or equivalent, use 2-3 tbsp red Thai curry paste and omit spices & tomato.
📝 sauté chopped zucchini or hearty greens in place of okra.
Nothing like an organization project to clear your head. Revamping my custom spice drawer happened in 2022! There is a story highlight saved with details on products. #kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista

The kitchen is my safe space. It’s where my thoughts fully make sense, where I make sense. I know what I’m doing in here. I move with ease. I don’t worry about saying the wrong things or the social anxieties that keep walls up. I can be weird here. I can be sad without shame. Joy and bliss too, without compromise.

This house is a hundred years old, a 1920’s bungalow with original floors and windows. I understood what it meant by a home having character when I fell in love with this one. It was actually a beautiful bathroom that won me over initially. The small galley kitchen didn’t feel welcoming until several months in, but that had more to do with my own baggage. Kitchen trust issues. The last one had leaky walls when it rained and was always under construction.

I put my energy into the living room first because I needed a place to sit and rest if I was going to work. I’ve started fixing up an accent wall in the dining room, but I always knew it would be the room that needed to wait. It is hard not to imagine myself here with company some day, but for now this is my personal freedom. The interesting thing about trauma is how difficult it can be to see the green lights once you’ve mastered stopping at red lights. Getting organized makes me feel secure. Took a year to pick paint colors with much trial and error. I’m not scared of the dark so I went bold. I work at night and want my kitchen to inspire that too. We’ve already fought it out over patched subflooring, crooked ceilings, and a warped cabinet door. Six months without a working dishwasher tested boundaries and I’m not sure I will ever appreciate the cramped fridge placement. But none of these things is enough to limit what I cook and create here. She gives in so many other ways, like the way sunlight finds me at just the right times.  The way the butcher block counters feel under my hands. When I walk, the floors talk back and plants whisper. She is a living, breathing thing and we are growing together. I am fiercely protective over who sees my work in progress. In the kitchen, I am learning how to love myself enough to breathe life into something else. #kitchenistadiaries

🥧 buttermilk pie crust / same technique as the tutorial in my holiday recipe book with simplified ingredients:
8 oz European butter 
4 oz (butter-flavored) shortening 
3 cups (15 oz) AP flour, used KA 
2 TBSP buttermilk powder
1 tsp Kosher salt
1/2 cup ice water 

Skipped the egg here just to see if I could. It works fine, but slightly easier to roll out and more color with an egg. Either way. After the dough comes together it is 30 min in the freezer / conditioning steps to create layers / 1 hour in the fridge. Then it can be rolled out. 

I’m happy to see other people celebrating despite it being a weird time of year for me personally. My daughter loves Christmas, I do not. I try, for her, for many reasons. I cook. Booked a trip to the west coast to save my serotonin. I’m definitely feeling the call to rest, do some more inner work, reflect on how to come back a little stronger. That is the cycle and I surrender to it, which I’ve come to learn is entwined with acceptance. The weight we feel is from carrying the hurt, masking it, not finding the spaces where we feel comfortable existing. It was only in surrendering to the pain and to the reality of who I am or what I am experiencing, that I have been able to move forward with the path to truly heal from it. But it’s not linear. And it comes in layers. Just as soon as I think I have myself figured out I realize there are parts of me that were still buried. The extra stressors this time of year expose work we have left to do. Triggers are abundant. Sunlight is waning. I do want to acknowledge that there are a lot of people hurting right now, many who are not ok and not able to find the words to say they aren’t ok. People who are lonely. Grieving families. Complicated relationships. Financial strain. It might be hard to only see happy celebrations and not much validation of how you actually feel. So, allow me to validate for you that I do get it. It is not easy. It will continue to be waves of hurt. You can put a tree up and be grateful for everything and everybody around you, but still be hurting. That is okay. I pray that you find ways to make it hurt less. It’s ok to cry. ❤️ #kitchenistadiaries

Pomegranate. For no other reason than wanting to play with something pretty and I had one sitting in the back of the fridge. Maybe in salads tomorrow. 🥰 I used to have the lyrics to this song taped to my mirror in high school. It’s on the “self-care” playlist for #kitchenistadiaries Volume 1 ebook. 

What’s your favorite way to eat the pomegranate arils? They are like tiny, juicy crunchy jewels. I like to pull them out as much as I can gently by hand so they don’t burst or bruise. Faster ways of doing it but that isn’t the goal when I just want to enjoy the prep. 😉
It’s giving seasonal depression with 🔥 views and a dope playlist. Big plans after the holidays to sit on this couch and binge my favorite shows with snacks and hot chocolate. #kitchenistadiaries

🥔Saffron mashed potatoes. It’s like wrapping yourself in a warm, luxurious blanket while the sun shines down on you. Also threw in some goat cheese, because I felt like it, but this could be cream cheese or sour cream in your world. As I was editing, I remembered I have an old blog recipe for the dairy-free version, so I will post that to Patreon tomorrow (Thursday) as well as notes for this take. Got some last minute holiday recipe gifts to post before Sunday. ❤️

Last time I made saffron mashed potatoes for lamb shanks. What would you serve them with? Saffron is a unique flavor, managing to be delicate and fragrant and floral while earthy at the same time. Nuanced and complex. A little bit goes a long way, so it’s not the kind of spice to shake liberally into pots. Taste and adjust as you first begin to use it in your dishes to see where those boundaries are. If you’ve tried saffron feel free to describe how it tastes to you in the comments, for others to read! 

#kitchenistadiaries

🍝 Would you invite me over for dinner? From my 2022 faves: Baked rigatoni with a spicy Bolognese sauce and garlic béchamel. #kitchenistadiaries 🍝

Notes:

Recipe for the sauce is on Patreon! Or, make a richer version with my oxtail ragu recipe, also on Patreon. Don’t go too heavy with cheese if doing the oxtail version.

Can do this with fresh or dried pasta, fresh just cooks faster so you need to be mindful of boiling and baking timing. Use rigatoni, ziti, or penne. After preparing the bolognese sauce, make a half batch of béchamel - same as you would for my mac & cheese recipe, slightly thicker. Instead of onions I infused the milk with garlic. Toss cooked pasta with half of the sauce. Spread some sauce into a greased casserole dish. Layer in half the pasta, spread with cooled bechamel. More sauce, another layer of pasta. Topped with shredded cheese and grated parm, then baked at 350°F until melted and bubbly.  It’s just like assembling lasagna. I used lactose-free whole milk and mozz in the recipe. Feel free to sub any other melty Italian cheese, like fontina.

Subscribe at patreon.com/kitchenista and you can also use that forum for specific questions on the recipes mentioned above.

#freshpasta #kitchenistaholidays

🐑 Braised lamb shanks / North African spices, preserved lemons, chermoula (herb sauce) / Saffron mashed potatoes, marinated carrot and cucumber salads. Did this one last year but ties in all the ingredients I’ve shown you over the last few posts highlighting the saffron mash. (It’s on Patreon!) Moroccan rub recipe is in my ebooks. Holiday dinners don’t have to be traditional, so gravitate towards the foods that make you feel good this season. 🎄 The obligatory holiday selfie. 🤳 

Happy Sunday or happy holidays, whichever is meaningful to you. Most importantly hope you ate good! We had duck, obviously. 😂 More on that later. I’m free-falling into my creative zone this week and the kiddo is fully equipped to get into hers too. Wasn’t the vacation we planned but it’s definitely the one we needed.

If you were part of my journey this year, in big or small ways, thank you. ❤️ #kitchenistadiaries #kitchenistaholidays #kitchenistasundays

Seared duck breast over grits, with sautéed collards and spiced cranberry agrodolce.  Baby I wore this song out when I lived in Florida. When I was going through it, I definitely used to dramatically drive home from work, past my apartments and towards the ocean - so I could go sit on the beach and cry. Gotta have a playlist for every breakup. I take it a step further and make it a motion picture. (I mean, it was Hollywood, Florida.) 

This was more of a release than wallowing in it. I’m not going through anything (yay for learning “no contact” with narcissists)  but the song came on. Volume 1 playlist. I said ooh, let me step into this for a night.

Very simple treatment on the duck breast. Salt and pepper, overnight in fridge to dry out the skin. Seared mostly skin-side down starting in a cold pan until fat was rendered. Basted in duck fat with roasted garlic and thyme. Finished at 125°F. No different than cooking a steak other than contending with the skin. The lighter color of the Rohan duck breasts threw me off but they were juicy, more mildly flavored compared to the bigger Magret duck breasts. I prefer these. Cooked some shredded collards and shallots in the rendered fat left in the pan, served over stone-ground grits. (Salt/pepper/butter.) 

Agrodolce is essentially a sweet/sour sauce. Working with holiday ingredients, so I went with cranberry, orange, sherry vinegar, maple sugar, black cardamom, cloves, allspice, peppercorns, vanilla bean, bay leaves (or bae leaves… ha.) 

Rushed the plating but it was freestyled so it’s cool. I think my favorite unplanned moment in editing was the sugar dissolving into the sherry vinegar like waves hitting the sand. This is probably something I will run back for Valentine’s Day because letting my heart bleed out onto a plate on holidays is both appropriately dramatic and cathartic. 

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista #duckfatganggang #kitchenistaholidays #kitchenistasundays #searedduck #rohanduck

Does anybody else use their empty 🍃 jars to store spices? 
🙋🏾‍♀️ #kitchenistadiaries 

Made a small batch of #berbere to season something for tomorrow. It’s cold and we’re going nowhere so I’ve been on this very intentional mission to choose colors and smells and food memories that conjure warmth. It’s leading me to some interesting places. Berbere is a gift from Ethiopian and Eritrean cuisine. It is warm, spicy, earthy and fragrant which checks all boxes. I googled several recipes to get the gist of what I wanted to experience. Fenugreek is the jar that inspired this particular journey. It had been staring at me the longest and not used often enough. Fenugreek smells like a nutty maple syrup. I used a mix of dried arbol and piri piri chiles for my heat and added smoked paprika to enhance the roasted spice flavors. A few of the recipes called for dried onion which I don’t have, but I do have dried shallots.

Spices can take you around the world without ever needing a passport. 🥰

Custom spice drawer products linked in my story highlights. 

🍃 Jar from @goldkine.mi. 🍃

Because I never get tired of sharing meditative kitchen work, and my buttermilk pie crust is a dream to work with when you just need to feel something. Cast iron skillets reinvigorated my love of pie baking this year.

The process showed in the video includes blind baking and an egg wash, details to both steps are explained in my holiday cookbook. It’s how you want to prep pie shells that will be filled with custard or fruit especially, and pie fillings that aren’t baked at all. 

Pies are an exercise in trust. Not a whole lot you can see until that first slice. As for this one… it was a pistachio pie experiment. The actual filling was a disaster, which happens. I forgot a key ingredient to stabilize the custard and overdid it on cardamom. The crust was delicious though. Sometimes we do all the right things and it doesn’t go the way we planned. Out of hundreds that I have baked, only a few weren’t edible. My joy was in the work itself so it’s never a total loss. ❤️ #kitchenistadiaries

🐠 Stewed fish collars and manioc (yucca), with sautéed collard greens, from 12.21.21. #kitchenistadiaries 

My phone photo album is a digital diary because of my work so it’s interesting to go back and see what I was thinking about a year ago. I was in my feels over this stewed fish and manioc, a pescatarian rendition of a Cape Verdean dish usually made with chicken. (The original stewed chicken & manioc tutorial is posted to Patreon.) Manioc is a starchy vegetable that creates a gravy all on its own. 

🐠 

Any time I work with lobster stock, which adds incredible depth and richness to seafood dishes, I’m reminded of lessons learned. If you were around for my sermons, then you know. Save some of that magic for yourself. *new reflections* But also, remember to use it. Sometimes we wait for this special occasion to do nice things for ourselves when really it could just be that you felt like tasting saffron on a Tuesday. I used to not use my specialty ingredients in content because it seemed like more work to provide a version that could be made with other ingredients. The people pleaser in me was always thinking about everybody else’s feelings before my own, to the point where I lost sight of what I really wanted to eat. Now I just make what I want and decide what makes sense to share. I don’t really care if it doesn’t fit the Instagram aesthetics or if it’s not a viral sound. In this ever-evolving dumpster fire of social media, I am sticking to what grounds me in real life. 

🐠

There is something special about the sweet spot between luxury and comfort. 

🐠

I go back and revisit my old video content a lot lately. I invested too much not to, plus I really love what I am doing right now. It’s cool to be in a place where you’re obsessed with your own shit. Synchronicity shows up in my work a lot. I recorded this a year ago but chose a different song tonight. The moment I dropped the spoon exactly when the lyrics line up was mere coincidence. It’s small, but it happens often and I choose to believe it’s a wink from the universe. So I keep going.

Best views of my 2022. Utah was shockingly gorgeous. Got to see it just before my 40th birthday this year, in March. It was a work trip but the kind that almost never happens, where you can enjoy the perks but be yourself and dress comfortably. I’m grateful for the way @traegergrills spoiled us and the gifts in the mail throughout the year. The bonus in Utah was linking with my chef friends. I have very few humans who I consider to be “my people” on this earth, but they happen to be scattered all over the country. The stars aligned for several us to be in one place for the first time, in Utah.

It was a friends trip, a food trip, a spa trip, and also lots of personal moments because as an introvert I make space to breathe. If I’m not in the kitchen, the ocean is where I instinctively go to find peace. The desert and mountains and sky follow closely behind. Places big enough and expansive enough for to me lose sight of the madness inside and remember that I am also part of all of these things around me. I’m still a little kid and need to sit by the window on the plane so I can touch the sky. Leave for a moment, release the parts of me that need to die, and then come back for my rebirth in the spring. 

💙 #kitchenistadiaries

New Year’s Day is also Haiti’s Independence Day. Every year since my daughter was a toddler, we merge traditions. She gets Soup Joumou alongside collard greens and black eyed peas, and sometimes smoked fish pâté. We talk about what the day means, and I think about how she carries the spirit of Haiti’s rebellion, instinctively. This year she stuck around for part of the lesson on how to make #epis, the Haitian seasoning base. After the fun was over she remembered she had better toys and left me to my prep, as she often does on holidays.

And as I often do, I try to lose my thoughts in the work. It is also our Independence Day, my independence, from a nightmare I should have seen coming because I lived it once before. The guilt and anger and resentment swirls and gags in the blender until it is something more useful. The spices, crushed. I never really liked cloves and because they remind me of him I like them even less. But when I teach her the things he was never here to do, I tell her about the cloves and how these flavors are part of her too. It is a beautiful culture and she will discover more of it on her own journey one day. My thoughts return to the duck that needs to marinate and the orange flesh of the kabocha squash, which will become our soup. 
#kitchenistadiaries

We lost a legend yesterday. Gangsta Boo was everything to me, especially eighteen year-old-me. Her music was raw and that energy made me feel untouchable at a time when it was needed most. When I put that bandana on and rode around in my jeep you could not tell me I wasn’t Gangsta Boo, in my mind, in the middle of the most suburbanish suburbs. Still rock my bandanas, except now it is in the kitchen. When I need to feel stronger, when I won’t take their shit. Permission to be just as bold. I’m grateful that I got to tell her what she meant to me and how it took another 20 years to take her advice seriously in Where Dem Dollas At. 🥲 I was sad and shocked to hear this news yesterday. But she would probably tell us to smoke something so you know what you gotta do. Rest in power, Gangsta Boo. 💨💔 #kitchenistadiaries

🇭🇹 Soup Joumou! This year I prepared Haiti’s iconic pumpkin soup with duck instead of beef. Gang Gang. 🦆🦆🦆 Another cool bonus was coming across the culantro to add to my epis for the first time. Started with 2 whole ducks broken down for parts and stock. Used boneless legs as my meat in the Soup Joumou. White sweet potato, turnip, and manioc (cassava.) I always forget how much of a marathon it is, so many different steps and 100% worth the time. Raven likes it spicy so she didn’t mind that I accidentally doubled up on scotch bonnet.

On January 1st, Haiti celebrates its liberation from France (1804). It was the only successful slave revolt in history. During colonial rule, enslaved Haitians were forbidden from eating soup joumou even though they prepared it. After the revolution, the soup became a symbol of freedom and is enjoyed most famously on the first of the year.

#Culantro (aka recao / chadon beni) - many have asked where I found locally, which was 168 Asian Mart. It’s labeled “Ngò Gai” in Vietnamese. 

Culantro is similar in flavor to cilantro but more robust. It is not the same plant. Used more often with heat/cooked vs using raw like cilantro.

I think I can count on one hand the number of times I have been lucky to find this. Even at the Asian market it’s been hit or miss!

Do you use culantro in your recipes, if so what for?

🦆 This is how I make ground duck meat. Using the metal meat grinder attachment on my stand mixer. The duck meat was chopped and left in the freezer for about 15 minutes prior to grinding. I try to get a mix of at least 20% from fattier spare parts. There’s also a good bit of solid fat that can be scraped off the skin if you take your time, which is especially useful if making duck sausage. It’s a lean product similar to ground turkey, but more flavorful because of the duck fat. If you also grind the legs, you’ll get even juicier end results. 

You get to help choose my distraction this week! Will it be duck lasagna… or… Jamaican duck patties? Vote in the poll. The ground meat is frozen in the meantime, waiting for this next adventure.

The boning knife is linked in my stories/highlight!

This plate was inspired by a similar soup I used to make in my 20’s, back in the Florida kitchen, before Kitchenista was a thing. Looked back to see what I was making a year ago on 01.11.22, so my thoughts:
 (1) A cast iron skillet is an elite pie pan for super thick custard pies
(2) This was a challenging and lonely period of time. I was still getting to know my new kitchen, half my good tools were still in boxes and I had no furniture in the house. It was also peak winter depression season all of which was a perfect storm. Emotions felt very intense at the time and I veered between throwing myself completely into a recipe as a distraction, or not being able to cook at all. But point is that I survived it and eventually found my way back to stability. Journaling and documenting my recipes daily has been a helpful tool for my mental health. For insight, I often look back to see what I was eating/doing/coping during my rough spots.
 (3) One of the best lessons learned from needing to work on my cookbooks year-round is that holiday recipes don’t have to be confined to a few weeks out of the year. I get to enjoy my desserts more when they are shot one at a time, as spontaneous weekend treats vs crammed at the end of busy holiday menus.

🥧🥧

The spicy lobster bucatini tutorial (available on Patreon) was one that took me a couple summers to get right. Working with whole lobster was new to me and it’s not something I budgeted often. 🐄 #Potroast, but make it sexy with a rich coffee gravy. Dropped the recipe on Patreon for those who don’t already have it! It is whole30-compatible, utilizing balsamic and dates for acidity and sweetness. When cooking with alcohol isn’t a concern, red wine is usually my go-to for braised beef - either works.

“Making pot roast look sexy” should be a category in some kind of award show, just saying. Photographing brown stews in general can be so challenging. These have always been some of my favorite shots over the years. 🥰

P.S. If you really want to go nuts, instead of chuck roast, braise short ribs or oxtail using the same recipe. Fattier cuts are best cooked the day before you eat it.  For a perfect sauce, strain after meat is fully tender but not yet falling apart. Chill the meat overnight in the gravy, then next day scrape off all the hardened fat and gently reheat to serve.

Recorded a quick rundown of today’s omelette. American-style which is easier to start with than French. I have always preferred cooking one big omelette rather than have kids waiting for another one to be made. So this is 6 eggs, 1 chicken sausage link (chopped), 1 small shallot (sliced), handful of baby spinach/kale mix, 1/3 cup shredded fontina cheese. Other: Butter, salt & pepper, pinch of smoked paprika and chili flakes, splash of lemon vinegar.

Tips:
(1) Cook the fillings first and then set aside. Use a paper towel to wipe out the nonstick skillet.
(2) Prep eggs as you would to scramble. Whisk eggs until frothy with a pinch of salt to tenderize the eggs, I add the pepper here too. Preheated skillet over medium-low heat, butter goes in to sizzle and swirl, then pour eggs in.
(3) Start by pushing the set eggs along the edges towards the center, like scrambling. Then use the spatula to lift up the cooked edges and tilt the skillet to let the raw eggs flow underneath. Do that all the way around the omelette, working quickly. 
(4) When the eggs are mostly set and top of omelette is just barely wet, turn the heat all the way down to low. Sprinkle cheese over the top to melt. Spread cooked fillings over half the omelette. Use spatula to flip over the top half of eggs over the filling.
(5) Let it sit for a minute to melt the cheese and finish cooking, with heat off. Slide omelette onto a plate or to a board to slice and serve.

🥞🥞🥞 Here’s how I modified my pancake recipe for powdered buttermilk, for those times when you don’t have liquid buttermilk on hand. My classic recipe calls for 1.5 cups buttermilk + 0.5 cups sour cream, so I replaced both to total 2 cups. You will measure the dry buttermilk (1/2 cup) and add that to your dry pancake mix. Then use water in your wet mix. As with any pancake batter, sometimes you need a little more or less liquid at the end so I held off on adding 1/4 cup water in the video. (The difference in adjusting buttermilk powder is negligible, although if for some reason it was short on liquid I would have needed to add more powder.)

Second part I wanted to highlight is a trick for separating eggs and incorporating the whisked egg whites *after* mixing the other batter ingredients. This creates a lot of lift for fluffier pancakes. It might seem odd that you do not need to whip the egg whites into a meringue but just until they are frothy is what works. If you want to add anything like blueberries or chocolate chips, do that are stirring in the egg whites.

The full recipe can be found in my digital cookbook, The Kitchenista Diaries Volume 1. Link in stories to download.

In the next Reel I will show you how they cooked up!

🥞🥞🥞 Part 2, buttermilk pancakes! Here’s how that batter cooked up using the powdered buttermilk substitute. (See the previous Reel.) Great results! Compared to the original recipe it is slightly lighter, mostly due to skipping the sour cream which makes for a richer pancake. If you cater, a big advantage of using powdered buttermilk over liquid is that you will get consistent results and don’t have to make room for extra bottles/cartons in the fridge.

I was thinking about all of the times the kitchen has been both the catalyst for change and a cocoon for growth in my life. I’m in my tenth year of #kitchenistadiaries which is a lot to be proud of and something I am continuing to remind myself to celebrate. I started this journey at 30, while I was a senior project accountant in the construction industry. After another breakup, frustrations with single parenting, and hating my job, I decided to start a food blog and pour into myself for a change. With no prior culinary or photography experience, I managed to learn enough creating food content for The Kitchenista Dishes to leave the corporate life behind. I’ve sold more than 30,000 self-published digital cookbooks without any traditional advertising. My recipes and words have been published in The Washington Post, Wine Enthusiast, and Food & Wine. I’ve catered private dinners, public events, restaurant collabs, and even a couple concerts. I’ve had fun doing what I wanted to do and trying what I wanted to try without pressure to commit to any of it. It was far from an easy ride. My path included periods of unemployment, unplanned pregnancy, moving back home, a whole lot of online abuse, chasing money, and some truly unfortunate partnerships. I’m a SA survivor and cope with ptsd, anxiety, and bipolar disorder. There are many reasons why figuring out my shit in the kitchen saved my life. Forging a career on social media has been nothing short of the Wild Wild West but I’m fortunate to have stuck with it long enough to reap rewards. I’m most grateful for the personal freedom in waking up to decide what my day looks like, the flexibility to travel, and moving into my first home. My life today looks very different than it did when I first escaped to the kitchen at 18. Today I am manifesting bigger goals. I love to teach and share my passion for food, which I truly feel is my calling.

#Saffron fettuccine. This was rolled out to a “6” on my pasta attachment. Fresh pasta is a very relaxing process to me. There are little tricks you pick up as you get more comfortable with the dough. I included shots of “laminating” the dough which I find makes it easier to roll out and less likely to rip. Can also be used to repair the dough if you do get a hole. Second tip is how I attach the end of the pasta sheet together to form a loop. Now it will feed through the pasta machine on its own, without needing to manage super long sheets or taking extra steps to cut the sheets down. Every couple rotations (look for the seam to pass), just turn the dial on your roller to the next number up, until pasta reaches desired thinness. Finally, a light dusting of flour or semolina helps to keep the rolled out sheets separated when you fold, and prevent the cut pasta from sticking.

🌶️ Step up your game in the kitchen. Recipe notes for duck fat fried chicken wings are over on Patreon. With the confit method, the wings are submerged in duck fat and cooked slowly at a low temp. In the second fry they cook at a higher temp. Results in meltingly tender meat and crispy skin. Duck fat enhances the flavor of poultry, making it taste richer.

🌶️ Serve the fried wings dry with a pinch of seasoning, or toss them in your favorite sauce after the second fry.  My go-to wing sauce is hot sauce + honey + butter, simmered until thickened to a glaze. (In the original video I made a homemade piri piri hot sauce.)

🌶️ Quick dip: mix equal parts bleu cheese, mayo, and sour cream, then adjust amounts for flavor and consistency. Add a splash of buttermilk if desired for a thinner dressing. Seasoned w/ Worcestershire, lemon juice, black pepper, and chives.

🦆 Grinding duck meat for #duckchili prep. I’m grinding my own duck meat for the chili because ground duck meat is hard to come by at the store. If you do find it, it’s almost always ground duck breast. That’s fine for quick cooking recipes like burgers. For chili, I wanted some leg meat mixed in which adds more fat and stands up to the longer time braising without drying out. You can treat ground duck like ground turkey in your recipes, or swap in turkey parts and try making your own ground turkey mix. Grinding meat at home means you are in complete control of the quality. For any type of chili, it allows you to experiment with different cuts of meat - think ground brisket or ground goat shoulder, as some other ideas. Today, duck.

Roasted broccolini, fennel, red onion. Roasted veggies are love. 🥰 #kitchenistadiaries 

Had a completely different plan for my broccolini but got into the weeds and just needed to get everything onto one pan and out of the way with minimal prep. Garlic oil, salt and pepper, lemon zest. Good toss, spread out on a sheet pan. 425-450°F depending on how your oven acts or whether you have to compromise with other things cooking. With convection roasting / air frying you can achieve more dramatic results. When veggies are tender and edges of the fennel and broccolini are browned, that’s good. Lemon juice, toss. Transfer to serving platter. Drizzle of your best olive oil and a good, syrupy balsamic for the razzle dazzle. I like my roasted veggies hot or at room temperature so it’s never really any stress once it’s done. For leftovers, the marinated roasted veggies are great eaten cold out of the fridge, chopped up and added to salads.

Roasted baby bok choy! In answer to a question in the comments on my roasted broccolini reel. Same exact process, same garlic oil, different flavor profile. I tossed the bok choy with togarashi + soy sauce + garlic oil, then after roasting it was finished with rice vinegar and chili crisp. Go for a hotter oven temp, 450-ish°F. Should be a good candidate for airfryjng too. 
Made these back in May alongside some crab wonton nachos with caviar. It was a whole moment. Whew. #kitchenistadiaries

Shout out to everybody who is thawing out after that ice storm. We had partial power (lights) but no heat, gas, Wi-Fi for a couple days which was not fun, then car wouldn’t start in the cold. It’s been a week lol. Any extreme weather situation is stressful. As a single mom it sends me back to traumatic memories of utilities getting turned off and having no money for emergencies or hotel, being too ashamed to ask for help and masking how bad things were. My mental health was in shambles. There was so much anxiety waiting for the next check to clear, only to repeat the cycle. Even though I have a long way to go towards financial security, I have also come a long way from where I was. Still, when unexpected chaos enters my life like it did this week, coupled with not having power and not having family here…my brain immediately went back to the past. I might as well have been 29 in my Florida apartment. Anxious, couldn’t sleep, hyper-vigilant, trying to shield my kid from seeing me scared. Resenting men who didn’t offer help. I was ok, but I wasn’t. I had what I needed, but in that moment it felt hopeless. It wasn’t until after power was back, that I stood in the shower and realized I needed to release heavy tears. It hit me that I’d been triggered. I’m still trying to coax the tension out of my body. We carry so much… it humbled me, how real that trauma felt all over again. I don’t know if I will ever outgrow the fear of losing everything, of being abandoned, or the next crisis. I’m learning that part of my healing has to involve trusting stability and finding comfort in peace.

Maybe that’s how I ended up with the menu this week. I was craving simplicity and veggies and things my body actually needs. Fridge and freezer clean out will result in minestrone, a big pot for our dinner and to last me through a few work shifts. But then after roughing it (LOL) my mind also went to extravagance. So I figured we are headed into March which makes me think of lamb…lasagna. I need the win, moreso I need to prove to myself that I can finish an old project.  Finally. 😉 #kitchenistadiaries

What’s the thing that brings you back to life? 🤔
When you feel drained, too much takeout, too little nutrients… what’s the thing you eat or drink to turn things around? 

It is a green smoothie for me. Today was spinach, cucumber, green apples, frozen pineapple and banana, ginger, mint, basil. Lime juice. A scoop each of collagen and green powder. Cold water. Blended. First sip through that straw is like tasting sanity. It’s more than refreshing, it’s restorative.

I gifted myself a morning routine last fall. I started journaling and that led to scheduling and to-do lists and menu planning and a bunch of other things that made me feel more like an adult. I decided adhd would not win. Get up, coffee, take my kid to school. Back home, straighten up the kitchen. Make the green smoothie. Get to work. Very little mess, nothing to cook. I keep bags of frozen banana already portioned. Ginger, peeled and frozen. I mix things up with different frozen fruit. Sometimes it’s a purple smoothie. Everything I need is in one freezer bin. When I am tired I make excuses so I left very little room to do that. In ten minutes I can have a smoothie and a clean blender. It’s doable. A healthy habit.

I was intentional about starting this routine before the winter because I know my patterns with mental health. And yet, I struggled during the holidays. Pushed myself too far with new projects. The loneliness and dreariness of this season kicked in. Then came COVID. Many weeks of fatigue and muscle aches, a different kind of tired than the one I am used to fighting with depression alone. Can’t keep up with housework. Don’t want to cook most days. I kept telling myself I will feel better if I just make the smoothie. But the guilt. The need to punish myself. So I talked myself out of the smoothie because of a list of tasks that comes first. Clean the fridge. Shop. Put groceries away. At this point I’m back on the couch.

Today I got up and cleaned. Made my smoothie. It’s a small thing that felt like a big thing while winter is actively kicking my ass, so I’m going to acknowledge it. It’s ok to start over. Routines are good. I’m working to let the good in. #kitchenistadiaries

🥗 When the Mediterranean diet comes to you. 🥗 

Some of the best food in the Detroit area is found at Mediterranean restaurants. It also happens to align with ingredients that agree with my digestive system that provide energy rather than drain me. THE BEST PART: it already looks like my meal prep and tastes like home cooking. I choose a few items to mix and match plates for lunches and dinners. 

My faves from local kabob spots:
🥗 chicken or beef shawarma (seasoned roasted meat)
🥗 hummus (chickpea & tahini purée)
🥗 baba ganoush (roasted eggplant purée)
🥗 Arabic salad (cucumber/tomato/onion) or other salads such as tabouli and fattoush.
🥗 Falafel (chickpea patty)
🥗 Saffron rice
🥗 Toum (garlic spread), harissa (chile condiment) 
🥗 Stuffed grape leaves
🥗 Fresh juices

My usual meal prepping routine is to batch cook - lean proteins, a bulk grain, veggie or salad options. It’s not too tedious but there are times when I don’t have the drive or strength to cook, particularly when coping with a depressive episode. 

Is it more expensive than groceries? YES. 
Is it less expensive than a private chef? YES.
This $70 order will feed us for 2-3 days. No cooking. Sold.

I no longer feel guilty about takeout. However I am working on holding myself accountable to make smarter choices. It also can’t be every day - I set a goal in mind to get back to the kitchen. This looks like:

✅  Ordering takeout at the beginning of the school week and planning one or two hot meals I can look forward to cooking after I’ve rested and shopped for groceries.
✅ Ordering takeout mid-week so I can reset the kitchen and recharge before my weekend cooking starts.
✅ Supplementing with smoothies during the day and ordering out in the evening.
✅ Ordering family style meals that can be reheated as leftovers.
✅ Ordering a la carte containers vs. combination plates that are more difficult to reheat and store.
✅ Setting aside a budget for takeout that is separate from my other payment options. (Ex: transferring takeout funds to cash app, so that I am in control of my spending limit for the week.)
✅ Saying no to fast food, opting for fresh ingredients that are prepared with care.

A year later of saving up and waiting for it to be available, it’s mine. 🫶🏽 Every time I step into my dining room now, it makes me look forward to executing the rest of my vision in here. Lamb shank stew! Tough meaty cuts like lamb shanks take many hours to braise until fall-off-the-bone tender. Sometimes I do that in my pressure cooker to cut down on time. But I enjoy cooking, so I try to carve out space to do it without the rush, without the pressure of having a plan for all the things that need to go into the pressure cooker from the beginning. Instead I turned to a Dutch oven pot, which allowed the lamb stew to simmer away on the stove top while I took my time working out the next ingredients. Then I tucked it away into the oven for a couple of hours at a time to slow cook without needing to be babysat. If you’ve made the “ras el hanout braised short ribs” from Patreon, this one closely aligns. It has the preserved lemon and similar flavor profile. Big grilled green olives from Trader Joe’s. Deglazed with vermouth. (It was a martini week lol.) I added some rose petal, smoked paprika, and black cardamom to my spice blend. (You will see me play with smoke & flowers a lot this spring!) I cooked a bag of dried chickpeas and added half to the stew, half will be used to make hummus this week. And then I had a butternut squash to use up, but I wanted the pieces to hold their shape in a stew. So I roasted the squash first, drizzled with honey and tossed in cinnamon and ras el hanout. Aside from the way the lamb just melted off the bone, the caramelized chunks of tender butternut squash were my favorite bites. Used up the very last of my duck stock in the broth, so that means I need to break down some more ducks this week. *birdman handrub*

A slow Sunday stew is an opportunity to think about what I am running low on in the pantry. It’s a way to use up the odds and ends in the fridge from my latest cooking adventures. It’s time to reset my mind. Savor. Connect. A slow-cooked stew might take all day to cook, but it’s mostly hands off. There are built-in moments to clean up, rest, and check in with my daughter. I’m finding my balance again. Getting back to enjoying my kitchen and prioritizing the meals I can both shoot + have time to enjoy. ❤️ #kitchenistasundays #kitchenistadiaries #lambstew #slowsundays #selfcaresunday

🌹 Happy #313Day! Detroit is known for its lamb chops but I think lamb ribs also deserve a spotlight. This was a recipe I played around with last spring, but I have been smoking lamb ribs since what seems like forever. There’s an oven baked recipe in my holiday ebook (pomegranate glazed lamb ribs) which I think is nice for the smaller cuts of NZ lamb ribs. The little racks will dry out more easily on a long smoke. These bigger American lamb ribs (sometimes sold as the breast) are more comparable to spare ribs on a pig. Depending on how they are sold by your butcher, might require some muscle to cut through where the bones are. You get the thicker, meatier lamb ribs with lots of fat running through it to keep things juicy on the grill.

🌹 Coffee rubs are also a staple of mine for the grill. Coffee works well to enhance richly flavored meat like lamb and beef. I like to add dried rose petals for a fragrant note in smoky and spicy rubs. Roses are used in North African, Persian and Mexican cuisine so I have found that it plays nicely in barbecue recipes.

🌹Artistically, this reminded me of how the grass starts to poke out from underneath the dead leaves and melting snow in the beginning of spring. I’m looking forward to revisiting my recipe, soon as winter releases its chokehold on us here in Michigan.

🌹 Aretha was my celebrity bonus grandmother in my head long before I ever moved out here, so it was super dope to feel that connection in new ways driving through the city.

☀️My latest dessert adventure was a saffron buttermilk olive oil cake! It tastes like sunshine, manifesting coins, and dream vacations in Italy. #kitchenistadiaries ☀️ 

You can get the original version (lemon buttermilk olive oil cake) over on my Patreon page. 🥔 Weeknight #mashedpotatoes! Just butter, cream, salt & pepper, bay leaf. The key is throwing a Russet into the pot to lighten up the mash while the Yukon Golds contribute a thicker consistency and buttery potato flavor. As for the dairy, personally I turn to lactose-free half & half or lactose-free whole milk. They also make lactose-free sour cream and butter now. Get into it. 🥳  Stick to creamy and full-fat substitutes rather than “light” for best results. For vegans, you can try any combination of non-dairy milk and butter but same advice applies. Mashed potatoes are a good dish to make if you need to get more confident with feeling things out, because they are forgiving.

🍄 Walkthrough for the mushroom gravy I made with my meatloaf. It would also be great for any cooked chicken, pork chops, steak, meatballs, etc. For the stock, a carton mushroom stock or mushroom base/bouillon & water works just fine. To make a richer tasting gravy you can use a chicken, duck, or beef stock. I have found that with mushroom gravies it’s fine to supplement with pantry ingredients versus using up my best stocks. You can always add a splash of soy sauce, coconut aminos, or Worcestershire for a meatier flavor/umami. Main thing to keep in mind is that mushrooms need plenty of time and space to brown properly or they will be short on flavor and kind of rubbery to eat, like canned mushroom texture. Let them release all the liquid and soften, THEN add salt and seasonings. Continue on with the gravy process after mushrooms are fully browned.

Get the recipe journals over at patreon.com/kitchenista (for #kitchenistadiaries & #kitchenistasundays tiers.)

🍄 Mushroom gravy. 🍄  New recipe journal posted to Patreon today! The complete journal is 2 pages and includes ingredient amounts. Save it as a cheat sheet next time you need a sauce for meatloaf, steak, chicken or chops. Great for simmering meatballs too. If you want a “smothered” situation just sear your chicken or chops in the same pan (before cooking mushrooms) and then set aside. Return meat to the gravy while it is still thickening. Simmer until fully cooked.

Simple fried #cabbage! Takes 5-10 minutes tops. Chopped cabbage cooked in a little duck fat (or bacon fat, or olive oil) - just enough to coat bottom of skillet. Medium high heat. Smaller batch or large skillet is best so the cabbage actually gets some color otherwise it all just steams. This was about 1/3 head of green cabbage. Less than $1.  Can’t get a cheaper veggie side than this!

Season cabbage with salt and pepper and cook until the cabbage starts to wilt. Toss and let the cabbage sit in the pan so it begins to caramelize around the edges, about 2 minutes. Stir in some garlic powder, onion powder, pinch of chile flakes. Toss again, let it sit again, 1 minute. Splash of vinegar to deglaze the skillet. Toss again, scrape up bottom of skillet. Cook another minute or two. Finish with a pat of butter, or not, but I think you should. 

You could throw in some actual chopped onions but honestly I just like to let the cabbage cook on its own some nights. If you want fresh garlic add after the cabbage has softened up otherwise the garlic tends to burn faster. The garlic powder and onion powder is perfect for busy nights and small batches. Also, a pinch of smoked paprika is lovely. Any vinegar, just need a splash of acid. I like apple cider or sherry. Lemon juice works too.

Enjoy! Plate was meatloaf, mushroom gravy, mashed potatoes and cabbage. Get recipes for the rest of the meal over on Patreon. Last one left to upload will be the meatloaf, so look for that as your Sunday post. ❤️ #kitchenistadiaries #kitchenistasundays #kitchenista #friedcabbage

Raven’s oyster journey has provided some of our most entertaining moments. Her first taste of oyster was around 3 or 4. We started with just sipping oyster liquor, evolved to babysitting the oyster and drowning it in condiments, gagging, deep regret, and finally to throwing oysters back like a pro and developing an actual oyster obsession. 😂 

One of the questions I get asked most is how did I encourage my daughter to try different foods. Here’s what worked:
🦪 exposing her to a variety of food smells and tastes in the kitchen as a baby
🦪 general “rule” was to at least give it one bite to try and/or small portion on her plate, but if it genuinely seemed that she didn’t like the taste of something, I didn’t force her to finish
🦪 we let her eat at the table with the big people and she now dines out with my adult friends comfortably
🦪 no kids menus at restaurants (we often share tasting menus and try everything)
🦪 letting her graze and choose what goes on her plate from whatever food was being prepared 
🦪 taking her grocery shopping and to farmers markets where she could roam freely, touch, push her own cart etc
🦪 letting her try things over and over again so long as it’s her choice! As with the oysters, sometimes it takes years to acquire the taste but I didn’t stop offering them to her. 
🦪 Because my menus are out there sometimes, I keep a healthy balance of “fun” frozen snacks and meals on hand so she can tap out of what I’m cooking if it doesn’t interest her. But 9/10 times she chooses to eat what I do!

P.S. check out @blackgirlsnoysters if you share our love of 🦪!

Hamburger helper using my ground duck chorizo! I was inspired by the last post about our childhood processed food cravings. 😂 Go check that out for some good 80’s-90’s snack nostalgia. I actually didn’t grow up getting helper, but I started liking the homemade version as a quick and inexpensive pantry meal that resembles mac & cheese enough to interest my kids. 

Here’s how to make it:

👩🏽‍🍳Brown a pound of ground meat in a large skillet and drain excess grease. (Lean ground beef, ground turkey, vegetarian crumbles etc.) Drain all but a couple tablespoons of fat in the skillet. 
👩🏽‍🍳Cook some diced onion, garlic, and spices of your choice. (I like to use my all-purpose rub from the ebook with extra ground mustard. Smoked paprika is a must. 😂) Stir in a couple of tablespoons of tomato paste or ketchup.
👩🏽‍🍳 Optional - Sprinkle the cooked veg with a tablespoon of flour to make a roux. I think the creaminess is better, clings to the pasta. Without the flour it will be a slightly looser sauce.
👩🏽‍🍳 Whisk in 3 cups broth/stock and a cup of whole milk. (I use lactose-free milk.) Traditional flavor can be achieved with beef broth or bouillon, but chicken stock works too.  You can do all stock and skip the milk, will still have some creaminess from the cheese. 
👩🏽‍🍳 Adjust seasonings in the sauce, adding a splash of Worcestershire or fish sauce.
👩🏽‍🍳 Stir in half a pound of dried pasta, such as elbows or shells. Simmer uncovered, stirring frequently until pasta is cooked al dente, which usually takes a few minutes longer than the package directions for boiling in water.
👩🏽‍🍳 Turn off the heat and fold in a cup of shredded cheese. Use something mild in flavor that melts fast, like cheddar, American deli, or gouda. Optionally, finish with some sliced scallion or chives.

🥓🥬 Looking for an easy vegetable dish for your spring holiday meals and Sunday dinners? These sautéed #collardgreens are the perfect alternative to braised Southern-style greens that need hours to simmer. Not only do sautéed collards taste amazing, but they’re also quick to make! You can even use pre-chopped greens to save time, though I recommend sorting through to remove tough stems.

Don’t mind my 🐥, he’s got an attitude because I chose 🐷 this weekend. Keep your options open in the kitchen. You can cook the greens in any fat you choose, including vegan options like olive oil or coconut oil.

Key recipe process steps are below. A formal recipe was also posted to Patreon for all subscribers. (Patreon.com/kitchenista)

* Prep the collard greens: Wash and destem the leaves, then slice them into 1/2” ribbons.
* Cook the bacon: Start with 3 strips of thick-cut smoked bacon in a cold cast iron skillet. Cook until crisp and at least 2 tbsp of fat renders.
* Add aromatics and spices: Add diced onions or shallots, sliced garlic, smoked paprika, black pepper, and chili flakes to the skillet. Sauté until the onions are soft and translucent.
* Add collard greens: Toss the collard greens into the skillet, a handful at a time. Deglaze with sherry vinegar after all the greens are added.
* Season to taste: Add salt if needed.
* Cook until wilted: Continue cooking until the liquid reduces to coat the greens, about 10  minutes. Finish when the greens are tender but still have some character left.

🐇 I was introduced to rabbit via family in NC/VA/MD. My dad prepared it once in awhile when I was younger, but I was usually the only other person in my house who would eat it. In my house, I have to fight an eight year old for the leftovers.

🐇 Cooking my first rabbit was a rite of passage! The biggest challenge initially was realizing that a lot of written recipes didn’t provide much detail on how to prep the meat. It also takes longer to cook than you’d expect for a lean meat. Nobody was around to help me at the time, so I googled how to carve a rabbit, relied on my existing knowledge of smothered chicken, and figured things out along the way. After getting smothered rabbit down, I tried other methods such as buttermilk fried and different types of stews and braises. I always return to smothered.

🐇 It was a treat when Uncle Benny visited from Baltimore or sent someone down with a frozen rabbit that he hunted. Smothered rabbit was a dish I got to serve a couple of my late uncles which was nerve-racking at the time, but also deeply meaningful. Especially once I got it right. Uncle Moon told me I was doing too much with the Marsala rabbit that one time hahaha, he never was shy about the critique but it always came with love and respect. He ate it and it was good, but his point was more to know your audience when serving country people. (That said, I think if he was around for my Italian pasta era, he’d reconsider and agree the rabbit ragu was fire.)

🐇 My cousin swore he didn’t eat rabbit, but once ate a whole plate thinking it was neck bones. So if you’re apprehensive about trying a new protein just remember it’s probably going to taste like everything else you’ve eaten that was smothered in gravy: delicious.

Was rabbit something you saw cooked in your household? Do you eat it? Have you tried it other ways? 
Share your thoughts in the comments!

Eleven years ago, I wrote the first post for #kitchenistadiaries and launched an epic culinary adventure. Over the years, I’ve been called a content creator, food blogger, internet chef, cookbook author, recipe developer, “highly opinionated self-taught home cook” or simply, “that kitchen lady on Twitter.” Call me whatever you’d like, just know that I changed my life doing it. As a single mom in her 30s, I discovered the courage to leave a corporate construction accounting career and pursue a passion for food. My name is Angela, but you came to know me online as “The Kitchenista.”

When I founded #kitchenistadiaries in 2012, I had no experience in professional kitchens beyond serving tables. So, I became a culinary student of the internet and taught myself how to cook, write recipes, and do food photography in my Florida apartment kitchen. Shortly after my blog took off, I faced a personal crisis - I got fired and pregnant in the same summer. I moved back home and struggled through a long period of unemployment. After exhausting my severance, I relied on public assistance for groceries. My days were spent nursing an infant, testing recipes, and juggling a teenager's football schedule. But through it all, I treated community-building and conversation online like a full-time job. I had no formal business plan. I was the photographer, the cook, the social media intern, and the PR agency. I sold ebooks and recipe cards like mixtapes out of my trunk. We were all figuring things out on our own back then. I created my blueprint.

For #shrimpandgrits that tastes like new money, without actually having it, try my tricks. #kitchenistadiaries 

🏃🏾‍♀️But first, save this post + #linkinbio  to subscribe on Patreon for the recipe.

Tips for luxurious shrimp & grits:

🦞 Lobster stock is up there with duck fat on the list of “secret ingredients that make everything taste good.” What do you mean you don’t have lobster stock ready to go in the freezer? 🤣🤓 Fake it with lobster bouillon base. All you need is a teaspoon to make a cup of broth that will enhance the seafood flavor of your sauce. This trick will blow your mind away, I promise. Especially if you don’t have any shrimp shells. If you do, always steep the shells in whatever stock you use for your sauce.

🦐 A quick brine with baking soda works like magic for plump shrimp with a springy texture. By the way, smaller shrimp are actually better than jumbo, in this application. They will cook up more tender. A frozen bag of peeled and deveined Red Argentinian shrimp from Trader Joe’s is my go-to lately. Ironically they taste a little like lobster meat.

🌶️ You might be inclined to reach for cayenne after sautéing the holy trinity. But consider Calabrian chiles. I’m obsessed with how the heat is balanced by bright, fruity chile flavor. Look for a tube of chile paste or a jar of chopped Calabrian chiles in the Italian pantry section of your grocery store.

🍷 Dry white wine, something drinkable and inexpensive is fine. Acidity cuts through all the richness you have going on in the spicy lobster sauce and buttery grits.

🐟 Umami is the savory sixth sense of taste, associated with meaty flavors. Boost your sauce with a splash of fish sauce or Worcestershire, both of which are made with anchovies.

🌽 Use stone-ground grits, cook slow, go easy on cheese. If you don’t live in the south, buy from legit southern brands online and keep a bag in the freezer for emergencies. I’m the kind of person who thinks* about how embarrassing it would be if Beyoncé showed up for dinner and all I had was instant grits. 😨 

(*99% of my anxiety-inducing imaginary scenarios involve Beyoncé, Oprah, or Gordon Ramsay popping up in my kitchen on an off-day. 🤣)

We prepped earlier in the day and by evening I was functioning on pure adrenaline to get those plates out lol.  Amazing experience getting to sit down with a restaurant owner and brainstorm flavors over cocktails and cigarettes, and then come up with an entire dinner experience complete with sommelier. In my mind this might as well have been a movie because who gets to go from sitting at a desk to serving oxtail and grits and illustrating tasting menus?

Fast forward to my 10th anniversary event at Frame last summer here in Michigan. Equally ambitious menu but this time it’s 40 guests x4 seatings and we will need to prep overnight to keep up. Oh and the oxtail is still a whole tail. Luckily I now had a solid four years of cooking this oxtail dish for clients and holidays, and I knew my recipe like the back of my hand. Which was necessary because everything that could have went wrong, did. Events are an extreme sport. Beyond stressful in new kitchens, but makes no sense how good the high feels when you see it all come together and it matches your vision. (Me, @thesofritoproject & Louisa crushed it. 💅🏽)

💭What if you actually sat down and figured out how to make the crazy ideas in your head come to life? What if wasn’t a matter of days, but years until you get it right? This is your sign to just keep going. 💪🏾

The secret to cooking #zucchini is fast, high heat and letting it sear before salting. If you salt earlier it tends to leech water and you wind up steaming instead of browning. 

———

Here’s a quick little recipe so you can flex at dinner time by handling the main dish *and* the side. 💪🏾 

1 TBSP oil or butter 
2 zucchini, sliced
salt & pepper
small bunch of ramps or scallions, chopped
handful of mint leaves, chopped
1 TBSP fresh lemon juice

Heat large skillet over medium high, add oil or butter to melt. Place sliced zucchini in pan, spread it out evenly and allow it to sear for a minute. Toss the zucchini. Season with salt & pepper and cook for another minute, undisturbed, until zucchini is just shy of tender. Add the ramps, mint, and lemon juice to the skillet. Toss the zucchini and scrape up any browned bits in the skillet. Serve immediately.

———

Recipe notes:

Mint and garlic pair really well with zucchini. I’m using fresh #ramps which give the dish the same garlicky flavor. (🌱 See my post from last week for more on ramps! 🌱) You could sub scallions or very thin sliced garlic cloves in the recipe if you don’t have ramps. 

The lemon brightens all the flavors at the end - splash of vinegar would work in the same way. That’s really all you need here. If you want a hint of spicy, add a pinch of chile flakes. Fresh cracked peppercorns provide heat in a more subtle way. When I have good veggies I like to just taste the vegetable, especially in spring/summer. 

For that reason also I used grape seed oil which does well in high heat and has a super clean flavor, then finished with a tiny bit of butter at the end. I worked with the same ingredients I already had outside for the chicken. Olive oil would work great here and so does coconut oil.

This green smoothie exists in the small corner of my life that stays organized. It’s part of a larger routine that has helped me get my mind together. I have visions of more of my life looking like this, but baby steps started with making green smoothies and documenting my habits in a journal. The recipe is a formula that allows me to swap in kale for spinach, mint for basil, lemon for lime. Mornings need to be on auto-pilot, so the small details make a difference. I’m very particular about how I arrange food in the fridge and freezer in order to quickly grab exactly what I need for smoothies. I leave a measuring spoon in the green veggie powder bag, because stopping everything to find the right spoon has potential to end without a smoothie being made. I store peeled sliced frozen bananas and ginger in portioned bags.  And as soon as I pour the green smoothie into my glass, I rinse the blender out and run the auto-clean function while I drink some water and take my supplements. (Nootropics and adaptogenic mushrooms have been critical in healing my brain, which is part of this current chapter of my journey.)

I’ve managed mental illness since I was in my late teens. After more than a couple of decades of debilitating chaos, peace feels a lot like a green smoothie, organized fridge, and practicing mindfulness in the morning. When things veer off-course — and they still do — there’s no telling when I’ll find my way back. But when I eventually do get it together, it’s in part because I created a routine that feels like home to my brain. The smoothie is my reset. It’s refreshing and replenishing, and makes me feel like I’m moving in the right direction. My desire to sip green smoothies as often as possible is a big motivation for staying on track.

With so many cooking oils to choose from in the grocery store, it can feel overwhelming. Understanding smoke points is one way to decide which oil will be best for your recipe, and from there you can consider other factors like flavor and nutrition. 

💨
The smoke point is the temperature at which an oil starts to break down and, well, smoke. Once the oil reaches its smoke point, it can give off some not-so-pleasant flavors and release harmful substances. Different oils have different smoke points, so it's essential to match the oil you're using with the heat level you'll be cooking at. When oil starts to smoke, it's time to turn down the heat or switch to an oil with a higher smoke point. It's always a good idea to have a few different oils in your pantry, so you're prepared for any recipe that comes your way.

🔥
Low heat (around or below 300-350°F): gentle sautéing, simmering sauces, baking, making salad dressings and marinades.

🔥🔥
Medium heat (around 350-400°F): regular sautéing, pan-frying, or roasting.

🔥🔥🔥
High heat (above 400°F): deep-frying, hard searing, or grilling.

I created a handy chart summarizing this info for the oils and fats most often referenced in my recipes. Use it to help select an ideal cooking oil for your recipe. It lists the vast majority of cooking oils and fats you'd find at the grocery store. Keep in mind that oils vary by brand, so the typical smoke point range is provided.
