🐄 Smoked, pulled oxtail. Your tacos will thank me. Recipe posting tonight for my #kitchenistadiaries Patreon baddies. 😎🔥 

How would you use smoked oxtail in your recipes?

Key takeaways:
🐄 Go to a butcher and ask for whole oxtail.
🐄 Cut in between the oxtail joints so that you can fit the pieces in your pressure cooker.
🐄 Smoke at 225°F until oxtail is safely cooked, 165°F. It will not be tender yet.
🐄 Braising in the pressure cooker is faster and requires less space and broth than submerging the whole oxtail in a pot or foil pan.
🐄 You can season the oxtail and broth however you like. For Mexican recipes, I suggest the Mexican chile rub from my ebook. The broth here was similar to birria and can be skimmed of fat and used as consommé.
🐄 Save those oxtail bones for future beef stock.
🐄 Ain’t nobody fucking with me, man.

I was working through some stuff with my self-esteem on this #kitchenistadiaries journey. (Still.) 

I’ve always loved teaching people how to cook, but I’m also ready to tell you more about how it has helped me survive. No matter where I was in my life or what was weighing me down, I always managed to find a kitchen. It often was not even my own kitchen, but I made do and created the space I needed, inside of me. I battle many things privately, like so many of you, and other things publicly. What I found was that nobody was coming to save me. I have my faith, but I also had to learn to become my own therapist, my own friend, and my own teacher. Pasta sessions give me a little bit of an opportunity to be all three at once.

Words were written for me, but I hope they help somebody that this reaches today too.

—Angela

(I recorded this about a year ago, for my Rabbit Ragu & Fresh Paccheri recipe, which you can find in my GUIDES tab.)

I have serious concerns for my safety and security. I don’t know how else to ask for help or how to stop this. I have gone to the police twice in the last two years for issues relating to my social security number being stolen and harassment online. I have asked business partners with the power to intervene and they would not. I hired a lawyer and filed a lawsuit against some of these people. Nothing happens overnight. I don’t know how to say all the things I need to say or want to say. But I woke up today to internet trolls threatening to publish my address. The bar is in hell when it is a criminal defense attorney who is also spreading vicious rumors that will bring me harm.

I’m a single parent in a city where I know nobody. I have already been through this before and moved for privacy. I’m really hurt to have been going through all of this alone for the last couple of years. I don’t want to bother everybody about this. I just want to be left alone. I left Twitter more than a year ago due to harassment escalating. I want to stop feeling unsafe in my own house. I’m dealing with trolls who have already established they have no issues stalking others.

This is sick. And it’s at the hands of Black women.

I don’t know what else to say. I’m genuinely heartbroken at this point.

🌽 Large batch cornbread. (Recipe on Patreon!) Catering taught me lessons about adjusting recipes on the fly. Scaling up to feed more people turned out to be a lot different on paper than in reality. Even things as simple as doubling my cornbread required some clever hacks to achieve the same quality at higher volumes. It was all trial and error until I figured out the new processes, and every time I stepped into a new kitchen I had to reassess. On the night I recorded this, I was cooking for my daughter’s school project late at night. The first time I doubled my own recipe, it came out way too thin and crispy in the larger pan. Tripled, it was perfect. Sometimes the recipes shed light on life lessons too. Scaling up, or growing a business, requires me to consider that I need adjusted methods to deliver my messages and products. #kitchenistadiaries 

Here’s what often went wrong when scaling up cornbread, and how to fix it:

🌽 Problem: Regular mixing bowls were not large enough to combine and stir ingredients without spilling. 
🌽 Fix: Upgrade to stainless steel commercial-sized mixing bowls. (Look in restaurant supply stores.)

🌽 Problem: 8-10” cast iron skillet can’t accommodate double cornbread batch. 
🌽 Fix: Bake in cast iron roasting pan or preheated aluminum pans.

🌽 Problem: Doubled batch cooked in larger pan resulted in thin cornbread.
🌽 Fix: Instead of a double batch, prepare a triple batch so that the resulting cornbread is the same thickness in a larger pan as it would have been in the original recipe. 

🌽 Problem: Larger pan of cornbread came out dry.
🌽 Fix: Small errors in measuring flour are magnified when scaling up, so you probably needed more buttermilk. Use your instincts to assess the way the batter looks after it’s mixed so you can catch potential issues before baking.

🌽 Problem: Larger pan of cornbread was wet in the middle.
🌽 Fix: Baking times could be different in a large pan. Start checking for doneness at 20 - 25 minutes but continue baking until center is dry.

For the original cornbread recipe + scaled up recipe, head to patreon.com/kitchenista, link in my stories.

I get a lot of questions about the buttermilk #piecrust I reference in other recipes. Here is the version that was originally posted to my blog. In the video, I’m rolling out the crust for a large skillet, but you can roll it out for anything. One batch makes enough for 2 deep dish single pie crusts (9-10”), or a double crust. (If you use the recipe for smaller/standard pie pans, you can squeeze 3 crusts out of it with tight trimming.). You can also divide it up into smaller portions for mini crusts, or galettes. I usually portion it out for 6 to 8 mini crusts in that case. 

Combine the dough ingredients similarly to making biscuits, however, you don’t have to be so gentle with it. The 30 min rest in the freezer and conditioning of the dough, should not be skipped if you want it to be super easy to roll out. I learned the technique back in 2014 from Chez Pim’s blog and stuck with it all these years.

It’s not a recipe you can do last minute, but if you make the dough in the morning, it’s ready to use by noon. I’ve not needed any other pie crust since writing this recipe. I’ve played around with lard and duck fat as replacements for the shortening which works well. Changing the proportions hasn’t been successful in other test runs, but I’m interested if you’ve made other changes that worked.

🦆🦆🦆 Bake with #duckfat if you’re really gang. Here are some ways you can utilize liquid gold in your recipes:

🥧 Chilled duck fat can be worked into biscuits and pie crust, in the same way you would use lard or shortening. I usually play with a 50/50 mix of butter/duck fat.
🌽 Use melted or sizzling duck fat in skillet cornbread. It’s just like using rendered bacon fat. The cornbread is best served warm.
🍞 If a recipe for fresh bread calls for a small amount of oil, melted and cooled duck fat will usually work too.
🌮 Fresh flour (and even corn) tortillas also benefit from a dollop of duck fat to keep them pliable, or use it to pan fry quesadillas and tacos. 
🍩 If you’re deep frying, add some duck fat to your neutral frying oil to elevate the flavor. This works for sweet or savory applications.

🍤 Piri piri grilled shrimp inspired by Shrimp Mozambique. Something light to throw on the grill while you have other things going. I like it spicy and messy, so I always do this with a good Piri Piri hot sauce and shell-on shrimp. 

Extended recipe/caption is available on Patreon for all subscribers. Happy Sunday! 🥰 

🌶️ Piri Piri hot sauce, also known as Peri Peri or Pili Pili, is a spicy sauce used in Portuguese, African, and other cuisines. It is traditionally made from the African bird’s eye chili, also known as the Piri Piri chili.

🌶️ Piri Piri is generally quite spicy. However, the complexity of its flavor makes it more than just a hot sauce. It’s used not only as a condiment, but also as a marinade for grilling or roasting meats, particularly chicken and shrimp.

🌶️ In the video I used rehydrated African bird’s eye chili peppers in the marinade but you could sub additional hot sauce or just leave the fire to the sauce itself.

🍤 Recipe notes:
1-2 lbs of jumbo/colossal shrimp, in-shell. Brine shrimp 15 min in cold water, salt, 1/2 teaspoon baking soda. Rinse and drain. Mash 10 garlic cloves with salt, lemon zest, lime zest, and parsley. (Optional: rehydrated chiles.) Add olive oil to get a thick paste. Toss jumbo shrimp in half the marinade with smoked paprika. In a saucepan, sauté the rest of the marinade with butter, smoked paprika, bay leaves, and plenty of piri piri hot sauce. Add white wine or beer, let it simmer. Grill the shrimp until they’re pink and opaque (about 2-3 minutes per side) and internal temp hits 120°F. Transfer the grilled shrimp to toss in the sauce just before serving.
Finish with lemon and lime juice. Serve with rice or crusty bread to sop up the extra sauce.

(For a stovetop option, cook smaller shrimp directly in the sauce until pink and opaque.)

🍊🥑🐟 Steelhead trout + citrus/fennel/avocado salad. 🍊🥑🐟 
Create your own sunshine. Today’s recipe video memory is from a salad I made often for clients, paired with pan-seared fish.  Steelhead trout is a freshwater fish. It has a similar color as salmon but a milder flavor and is usually a bit thinner than salmon filets, making it perfect for pan searing. In the past, I’ve served the citrus salad alongside roasted salmon, which is also a good alternative here if you can’t find the trout. Use the slow-roasted salmon recipe in my Volume 1 ebook for that. From the same cookbook, you’ll also want to use my cracked pepper blend for the seasoning here if possible. Since the fish is only being hit with simple salt and pepper, freshly ground pepper stands out. The mix I use has hints of coriander and fennel which plays into the ingredients here.

For the salad, use the best citrus you have. If you’re compelled to amp the citrusy flavors up, you could grate some zest into the vinaigrette. The salad is actually great on its own, in which case treat the avocado as your protein and just serve larger portions.

June 2021. This was my take on a classic comfort food: #lasagna. I like to think of it as a harmonious marriage of Italian-American traditions and classic Italian techniques. Adorned with rich layers of a spicy bolognese sauce and creamy béchamel, wrapped in delicate sheets of homemade pasta, this lasagna is always an unforgettable experience. 

Let’s talk about the bolognese first - the soul of any lasagna. Typically made from ground beef, pork, or veal, this sauce is more complex than a simple tomato-based spaghetti sauce but doesn’t bear the heaviness of an oxtail ragu. To give it my signature touch, I swap in Italian sausage for the ground pork to take advantage of its seasoning. I was never a huge fan of celery, so I often substitute fresh fennel alongside the minced onions and carrots in the soffrito.  Then I extend the bolognese with whole tomatoes and intensify the flavor with a kiss of anchovies and Calabrian chiles. The sauce cooks for several hours and needs to cool afterwards, so this part is ideally done the night before.

Instead of going the Italian-American route of using ricotta in the layers, I prefer béchamel. Béchamel is a creamy, indulgent sauce that stays beautifully moist during baking, unlike ricotta, which has a tendency to dry out. For me, this velvety sauce elevates the lasagna and complements the rich bolognese perfectly.

And of course, no self-respecting lasagna would be complete without good pasta. I put a great deal of love into making fresh pasta sheets. Duck eggs and semolina lend a richness that brings the pasta to life and makes it a joy to roll out.

Lastly, freshly grated Parmesan goes in between layers for subtle sharpness. I don’t like to overdo it on cheese, so just the top layer gets a crown of melted fontina, which lends a gooey, melt-in-your-mouth factor that reminds me of the lasagna I loved as a kid.

When you’re prepared to embark on a weekend culinary journey, my recipe awaits on Patreon. (Take my word for it, you’ll want to stretch this out over a couple of days, especially if you’re crazy and plan to capture the entire process on film. Ask me how I know!)

🌶️ 🐑 🌹 Chile-rose smoked lamb shoulder! I’ve always had a love for the unexpected, which is why I couldn’t resist adding the floral notes of dried rose petals to my chile spice blends. I promise you, it’s a game-changer. The combination of earthy heat from ancho and guajillo chiles, aromatic spices, and surprise floral accents, contrast beautifully with the deep smoky flavors of the barbecue.

My recipe walks you through an easy-to-follow smoking process that will leave you with a tender, juicy pulled lamb shoulder with an amazing bark. Feel free to substitute your favorite BBQ rub if you’d like, the technique will be the same. If you can’t get your hands on a lamb shoulder from a local butcher and ordering online isn’t an option, you can try subbing a small pork shoulder or even a beef shank. For pulled bbq meat, you want a well-marbled cut of meat that is big enough to withstand the long smoke times. This pulled lamb is perfect for tacos, nachos, sandwiches, or any other dish where you might use barbecued meat. Given the richness of the lamb fat, it’s best served steaming hot and alongside something acidic, such as a tangy coleslaw.

🫐 Recipe for my blueberry-blackberry cobbler is on Patreon! 🫐

Fruit cobblers on the fly are some of the best summer desserts to consider. They are the kind of thing you can decide to do at the last minute and don’t require precise measuring. I made use of some specialty ingredients I had on hand from pasta, like Buffalo-milk butter, duck eggs, and semolina. Semolina is made from wheat but feels like a very fine cornmeal. You saw it used in my fresh spaghetti recipe, and it was also used to coat fish for frying. In the cobbler, the semolina contributes flavor and texture to the biscuit topping, as well as the pretty golden color. The color is also enhanced by the duck egg, which has a rich and fatty yolk, perfect for baking - and pasta. The berries in the cobbler are seasoned with a pinch of cardamom, which is fragrant and mysterious. It’s a fairly expensive spice, so once you have it you should definitely play with it! Add a pinch to cookie and cake batters, coffee grounds before steeping, sweet potato or squash pies, ice cream base, or smoothies. It works in savory applications too, especially in complex spice blends such as curries and ras el hanout.

This cobbler was freestyled, but I had an idea of what I was after from my peach cobbler recipe, which in turn originated from my 3-ingredient biscuits. Mastery of home cooking is knowing how to adapt your ingredients for whatever ideas or cravings spark your interest. When you learn what each ingredient contributes to the dish, file that nugget of information away for the future. Explore the connections between similar recipes.  Worry less about screwing up and more about how amazing it is going to turn out. Getting comfortable experimenting will not only lead to delicious results, but it can minimize the frustration of buying extra ingredients for one recipe but letting them go to waste.

Duck fat and pasta, my two favorite worlds colliding… 🍝

Recently I shared the original #chickenparm recipe from my retired blog. Today I shared an updated version of the recipe which matches the video I shot here, utilizing #duckfat in both the sauce and the frying oil. The result was amazing, like a southern-countrified version of the Italian-American classic we all love.

Duck fat has a distinct savory flavor that is different from pork fat, but works in similar ways to impart richness. Preparing a marinara sauce with duck fat reminded me a lot of sugo all’amatriciana, which is made with cured pork jowl called guanciale.

More tips:
🍝 Parmesan rind simmers in the sauce for added umami. Always save your leftover rinds for soups and sauces!
🍝 When frying the chicken cutlets, use a high-smoke point frying oil such as grape seed oil or light olive oil, then add some duck fat for flavor. (If you remember in the original recipe, I used a little bit of butter - same idea.)
🍝 For the breading/flour mixture, I amped up the original seasoning to incorporate smoked paprika. This complemented the direction duck fat took the flavor profiles, and created a deeper color in the chicken coating.
🍝 Processing the bread crumbs to a finer crumb makes them stick to your chicken cutlets better!

Full recipes (original version and duck fat version) are available to all subscribers at patreon.com/kitchenista.

Later this week, I’m releasing a new cookbook! The Kitchenista’s Summer Cooking Handbook. Before the big day, I wanted to share how it started. This is my fifth self-published digital cookbook. Most of the photography dates back to 2016-2019, which is crazy because every time I pull a book together I realize how massive my content library is. When I retired the blog, I started converting many posts to cookbook recipes. This is the first of those projects. I also pulled in a lot of my old catering menus.

I needed sunshine back in my life and I was sensing a lot of other people do too. So, it’s a summer recipe collection - but it’s also the flavors and colors and smells that make me happy. I drew from memories when I first started my blog, overlooking palm trees and beach views, and from the summers I spent in Virginia learning to grill in our backyard. I think in terms of formulas and systems, so much like the Holiday cookbook, this collection is made up of recipes you can prepare individually or as part of a cohesive menu. There are sides, salads, apps, and main dishes with coordinating spice rubs, bbq sauces, condiments, etc. There’s a ton of info on grilling for beginners, and the recipes are compatible with charcoal/gas/pellet smokers. I included notes for using a grill pan to prepare some things indoors. This is a journey and you’ll get more out of it the more you use it. The initial release will be digital, and by fall, a printable version will be made available.

Behind the scenes of self-publishing - I did all my own photography, recipe development, writing, and graphic layout. For the first time I was able to use AI for editing, mostly in ChatGPT. Along with creating the book, I documented my process. It’s my hope to one day teach others how to self-publish. 

But for now… I’m excited to release my baby. Tentatively 7/11 - 7/12/23, giving myself some wiggle room to make sure things are up and running with downloads. Join the email list at shopkitchenista.com for updates - or if you are a Patreon subscriber, you’ll get a notification (and discount) when the cookbook is available!

Back with some Sunday thoughts:

*Thank you from the bottom of my heart for your patience and grace. I needed to take an unexpected and unannounced absence to tend to my health. I’m currently locked out of my @patreon account but hopefully will be able to send out a message tomorrow and new posts. 

*This song by #chinchilla has literally been on repeat in my brain all summer.  A weirdly dope thing happens when I cook/edit on the fly and everything syncs up to lyrics without trying. 

*I live in my head/music/thoughts/heart.

*More thank you’s to a handful of people who allowed me to lean on them. For the first time in awhile, I needed help with cooking and a lot of things I was used to doing for myself (and others!) My mom and godmother both visited this summer which was amazing. 

*I ate the same salad ALL summer. Part of my unmasking journey is accepting how happy that actually makes me.

*Sometimes my kitchen gets cluttered and I’m not trying to hide that anymore.

*Meal prep buddies! Do you have one? I never did before, but it’s the best thing ever and I’m so grateful to have a friend nearby to share that space. Made a huge difference starting the school year with easier dinners + she was the extra motivation I needed to get back into the kitchen.

*Raven is doing good and started 4th grade! She took a baking class this summer and loves to help out more in the kitchen when she can, like tonight’s cornbread!

*It’s hard to ask for help when you’re afraid not to be seen as capable or independent. There was some internalized ableism for me to unpack. 

*It was problematic that it wasn’t safe for me to speak up in my community when I needed real support.

*I’m grieving the loss of some things that weren’t for me, but also hopeful about moving in a direction that allows me to provide myself with the accommodations I need as a neurodivergent person.

*Easing into fall with a whole unreleased summer project on the back burner. When I realized the fashion industry is debuting 2024 spring/summer looks right now, it validated…a lot. Look at me, early for a change?! Stay tuned.

❤️angela

Thoughts on a rainy Saturday…
* Recipe journaling helps me to organize my thoughts in ways that I can’t do with traditional recipe layouts.
* I show my prep work because one of the worst things to happen to the culture of home cooking (thanks to TV) was the delusion that every meal can be accomplished in under 30 minutes. Not only does it set up unrealistic expectations for home cooks who strive to eat healthy, fresh produce, but it diminishes the work of professional cooks who do this so you can eat a plate without thinking about it.
* Most people think they don’t like raw kale salads because the greens weren’t massaged for tenderness or the dressing didn’t properly balance the bitterness.
* Buy bagged salad mixes if you aren’t up for the prep. That’s how I eat my salads during the week. Add whatever fresh fruit or veggies you want. 
* This was one of my favorite fall meals. Kale salad with apples and fennel, roasted butternut squash, smoked baby back ribs with a fig glaze. Everything tasted good together on the plate.
* Buy the fancy vinegars. No recipe is going to specifically call for saffron balsamic buy why should that stop you? (You can sub an apple cider vinegar, sherry vinegar, or white balsamic here.)
* The al-go-rithm doesn’t like 90 second videos so it’s weird they gave us the option, but I’ll continue to show you the long edits…because I can.

🥜 It’s so good. On everything. Check out the new posts on Patreon - how to make this #peanutsauce, how to poach shrimp for meal prep, and my favorite Asian pantry staples to enhance your meal prep recipes. 🥜

This noodle bowl/shrimp salad situation? Hit. At around midnight, after hours of forgetting to step away from the computer, after a couple of days of trying to do too much in the kitchen and paying for it in my body, I finally remember to eat. And I was so grateful that I at least got this part of my meal prep done to make it possible. There’s nothing more frustrating than wanting to eat well but knowing that nothing you could possibly order will fill that specific void in your empty stomach / culinary soul.

I’ve been taking a lot of time to reflect and adjust how to give myself a break, whereas, in the past, I would not have wanted to take shortcuts. Every day, a fresh meal. I pushed myself to be creative in exhausting ways, treating most recipes like outfits - never wearing the same one twice. Now, my goals are different. I want to avoid coming up with a brand-new plan every day for lunch and then do it again for dinner a few hours later. I like the comfort of knowing my favorite peanut sauce is waiting in my fridge, ready to be drizzled over a bagged salad mix and avocados, if nothing else. But usually, there is a lot more I can grab, like a few pieces of last night’s chicken breast or a can of Trader Joe’s smoked salmon. This weekend, it was poached shrimp. The peanut sauce is the star, regardless of what she’s drizzled on. And even though I am technically eating the same thing every day, it never seems that way when you remix all your ingredients.

Read more over on Patreon.

And hello! We begin another week. Lots to share. ❤️
—Angela

🎧 fall cooking flow. (tips in caption)

🖼️ fig-glazed pork ribs/roasted butternut squash/kale salad with apples and fennel

🎨 @diasporaco whole spices + mortar & pestle.

Buying whole spices is a different experience. Creatively pushes you into new directions + elevated aromas and flavors + hands-on and visual experience to play with the different shapes and colors. 

If you enjoy cooking with a variety of spices but usually buy them on the shelf pre-ground, the next step up is to start making your own blends. It would be like only buying 🍃 prerolls and never appreciating the ritual of flower. In both cases you save more money over time to grind it yourself, ideally just before smoking.

Same goes for sauces, like your favorite summer bbq sauce recipe. Swap out the ketchup/tomato for fruity seasonal jams or pastes, then sweeten to taste. In the fall, I turn to dark, sticky sweeteners like molasses, sorghum, and maple. For acidity, apple cider vinegar still works, but you could also try balsamic or Sherry for something different that complements dark leafy greens. Doctor it like any other bbq sauce. Now you have a fall/winter glaze for smoked and roasted meats. 

📗 If this is helpful please consider supporting on Patreon, where you can access my recipe library and tutorials. Check this weekend’s feed for the kale salad recipe.

🍝 Happy #NationalPastaDay! Taking a detour from duck soup to reminisce about the chokehold that duck eggs have on me. This saffron pasta though. 🤌🏽 

My pasta notes are available on Patreon. Or, grab a pack of fresh pasta from the store so you can get right to the crab. This was Dungeness, but any picked crab meat would do…I’d try to source blue crab on the east coast. 

Start with sautéing shallots and garlic, then kick it up with lemon zest and Calabrian chili — make it as mild or spicy as you prefer. Deglaze with white wine or vermouth, add a bay leaf or two, and let the flavors simmer. Whisk in more butter, fold in crab meat, then marry it with freshly cooked pasta, using a splash of pasta water to perfect the consistency. Finish with lemon, chives, Calabrian chile oil. (No parm. Use that to roast some broccoli on the side.)

Pairs well with a Negroni, Americano, or Martini. 

#kitchenistadiaries #NationalPastaDay #CrabPasta

From the Patreon archives, a recipe perfect for fall. I really enjoyed the flavor of the short ribs and loved how easy it was to roast a butternut squash at the same time. Sometimes with mushrooms alone, things fall short, but incorporating the mushroom powder elevates the whole dish. I put some notes in the recipe about the seasoning and I will film a quick demo of how to make your own mushroom powder later this week.

My energy was zapped halfway through the cooking process, which is not unusual for me this time of year and I’m guessing some of you deal with that too. What I like about braising cuts of meat like this is that there are plenty of opportunities to rest in between. Season the meat, and stick it back in the fridge for a day. Sear the meat and pop it in the oven for a few hours = nap time. If you’re up for it, finish the sauce and cook the mushrooms to serve right away. But honestly, it’s even better the next day, so my recommendation is to let it cool, transfer the whole pot to the fridge, and then the next day you finish it off. Plus after the fat gets cold it all rises to the top of the sauce and hardens, so that is much easier to skim versus a hot sauce.

🐇 Silly rabbit, tricks are for kids. 🪄

A look back at this smoky rabbit ragu and fresh Paccheri pasta for my #jayzpastapairings series.  We tend to think of rabbit in the spring but it’s also part of the fall hunting season. Rabbit is a lean, sustainable protein that cooks similarly to chicken; the legs will take considerably longer to tenderize making them perfect for braising. I recommend working some duck fat or bacon fat into the pot as needed for extra flavor and easier browning of the parts. As for the ragu, it’s my usual formula adapted from recipes like the oxtail ragu. Less tomato, white wine, and finished with a little cream. Both the rabbit parts and the ragu spent a little time in the smoker while I made my pasta. I finished the plates with carrot top gremolata and grated parm.

Used semolina, flour, and a mix of chicken and duck eggs for the pasta dough. The rolled pasta is called #Paccheri - named after the Neopolitan word for slaps, like the sound they make. It was a challenging but fun experience figuring out the right sizes and technique to cut out my pasta squares and roll them by hand. Still one of my favorite shapes since making this.

This was a marathon cooking session to keep my head above water many moons ago. Will likely revisit for a future recipe, with more approachable methods. ❤️ 

#kitchenistadiaries #pasta #freshpasta #pastamaking #rabbitseason #rabbitmeat #ragu

These smothered smoked turkey wings were prepared for my clients during the holiday season a few years ago. I adapted my original recipe for a twist to the traditional oven-braised method. Instead of beginning with a sear in a pan, the wings are first smoked directly on the rack, introducing a deep, smoky flavor and amazing color. Post-smoking, the wings are braised in a homemade gravy, enriched with the “trinity” of onions, bell peppers, and celery.

I served these with horseradish mashed potatoes and a pot of smoked turkey collard greens. For dessert, peach cobbler was also prepared on the smoker. It was a manageable menu for a big group. The nice thing about turkey wings is that they make their own gravy. If you’re not a fan of doing the whole bird this is a great alternative.

🦃 Both the smoked and oven-baked smothered turkey recipes are shared with all Patrons at patreon.com/kitchenista

I was denied justice in a case for defamation against four parties who participated in an ongoing cyberbullying campaign against me for the last two years. While I wholeheartedly disagree with the rulings of the court, I am glad this is behind me.

This summer, I considered taking my own life. After decades of abuse, I was done. Today I’m here, and I want to be here. And I will speak my truth.

The laws need to be changed to protect digital spaces.

What these clout-chasing ABUSERS did:
- Illegally accessed my social security number
- Inciting harassment of their audiences
- Threats to expose my private information, including the locations of my family members
- Disparaging my body
- Disgusting remarks about my minor child
- Weaponizing my mental health diagnosis and remarks related to r*pe 
- Starting false rumors that I “ran off” with donations ($55.)
- False allegations that I operated anonymous social media accounts to harass people
- Publicly humiliating me throughout court proceedings
- Exposing information about my mental health care, accounts of emotional distress, and suicidal ideation. These documents were read by a Black woman attorney for an audience of nearly 40k, for jokes. 

Suicidal ideation was a joke to them. That’s how far this went. 

I spoke out against a known scammer - then additional harassment resulted from refusing to use my platform to support an unlicensed “anti-doxxing” charity (the irony) or shut my mouth about their foolishness that jeopardized a necessary movement. 

The people who participated in this smear campaign include married couples, queer Black folks, and Black women well into their 50’s - in other words, people who knew better, but had no problem threatening my livelihood. What was most disappointing was the “professionals,” who included licensed social workers, an attorney, a television cast member, and alleged millionaire. Many of these people engaged with and became anonymous trolls.

These matters required a cease & desist, police reports. When I made cries for help, I was mocked. I lost friends, and was unable to work. I saw how unwilling those around me were to bear witness or offer protection. (Continued.)

“Now the world will get to see it’s own reflection
And the anointed can pursue their own direction
And if you’re wrong and you’re too proud to hear correction
Walk into the hole you dug yourself, f*ck a projection
See me in my freedom taking all my land back
They said a lot against me thinking I’d just stand back
I got my legs beneath me, I got my hands back
A lot of people sabotaged, they couldn’t stand that
I turned the other cheek, I took blow after blow
There’s so much crisis in the world ‘cause you reap what you sow
When you keep what you know is meant for someone else
The ditch you dig for them, you might just end up in yourself
I’m in the secret place, I keep a sacred space
They keep showin’ their hands, but keep hidin’ their face
If I’m a messenger, you block me then you block the message
So aggressive, the world you made is what you’re left with
Pride and ego over love and truth is f*cking reckless
Y’all niggas got a death wish, the stupid leaves me breathless.”

Words from Lauryn that I will never get tired of sharing.

As Nas said…
Ain’t duckin’ nothing. 

I’m HERE, and the only thing abusers get to do from this point forward is watch me win.

It’s weird to have fans but not feel seen. So I’m trying to find the courage to let those who care start “seeing” more of me.

Random things I like that don’t involve ducks: 
Club sandwiches. Wind chimes. Basset hounds. (I want one so badly.)

I’m just biding my time until the aliens return to take me home.

My last hospitalization was in Feb 2019. I got my angel wings then. The tattoos on my arms partially cover scars. A few days later, I catered a party as if my life wasn’t in shambles. For more than a decade, I let a lot of abuse go unchecked because of how I would look to respond to it.

This time, it was a gradual decline, so slow I didn’t see it at first. I blamed exhaustion on work, then COVID. But as my body began to heal, I still couldn’t shake the numbness. I had good hours, not days. I stopped cooking. 

To lose trust in the thing you built that saved you from all the other BS… 

Grey’s Anatomy was my safe space but this summer, I turned to SciFi and binged The Foundation. I’m obsessed with dinner parties gone awry on reality tv. (So far this season of Southern Charm is *chef’s kiss.*) I keep a list of Real Housewives who cook.

I’m grateful for people who allowed me to be human, let me cry, and didn’t try to diminish my anger.

When I paused creating content, I found neurodivergent voices - late-diagnosed ADHD/autistic people, many with CPTSD, similar trails of abuse. For the first time, I saw myself reflected. *That* saved me, maybe. Trauma has a new context—the intensity of feelings, repetitive thoughts. I can write articulately but struggle to communicate in ways that constantly put me in danger. It is gut-wrenching to realize these things at 41. 

It was hard to work through that while I felt unsafe to be vulnerable. I will not be silenced ever again. I was unsure how to begin unmasking, and now I just don’t care. I am who I am.

I need a village who gets it. Our world is different to navigate. It’s heavy. But I have a daughter who’s a lot like me. She doesn’t yet understand why I fight to be here for her safe space.
 
I shouldn’t have had to go through what I did, but maybe somebody else won’t because I share my story. #kitchenistadiaries

“Why do you like duck so much?” Because of all the cool shit you can do with it, like smoking duck necks. Smoked turkey can’t compete, and since so many of you gave up pork I’d suggest giving this a try instead. The fat content in duck + its savory flavor do a lot for greens, stocks, beans, soups, gravy, and everything else you would simmer with smoked meat. Plus, necks are super cheap to purchase and there’s not a whole lot of work involved. I smoke a batch when I already have something else in the Traeger, then store them in the freezer for future use.

I can’t stress enough that smoked duck has produced the best collard greens of my life.

(Sharing for the culture… Just tell them who taught you. 🫶🏽 I feel strongly that duck could impact soul food in positive ways if it became more accessible in grocery stores and used in our restaurants.)

🦆 Lightly oiled, seasoned with salt, and smoked at 200°F till they hit 165°F. This will take 2-3 hours.
🦆 The necks do have a little bit of meat on them, but you’ll need to finish by braising /simmering in liquid until tender. 
🦆Duck necks have small bones, so I wouldn’t let them fall apart in the pot. Remove and shred as desired.
🦆 You can follow a similar process for duck wings.

Last Thanksgiving I tested out a few adventurous recipes. Would I try to squeeze in fresh pasta on a busy day ever again? No. 😂 Was I feeling myself for finessing it? Yup. 😏

Here are my thoughts and lessons learned:
- Duck egg & semolina pasta, of course. The ratio for extruder pasta is different, much harder to knead.
- There is a Macaroni attachment with the extruder but the pasta is tiny. I was worried about how it would work in a baked dish so I opted for the larger size. It’s more like rigatoni or penne which is also fine for mac.
- Extruders work extremely slow, patience is needed.
- You may need to manually open the tubes if some get pinched closed in the process of cutting the pasta.
- I haven’t tested this enough to confirm, but using fresh pasta thickened the béchamel sauce a bit more than I expected. There are too many variables like the cheese I used and baking time, to know for sure how I would adjust for that.
- One of the cheeses I used was Raclette which is super melty - but only when the mac is hot!! I’m particular about not liking baked macaroni and cheese at any other temperature so this didn’t bother me. 
- I added minced shallots instead of doing the onion steeping. Loved the flavor but I don’t like recording and having to explain that it’s not a smooth sauce for that reason lol.
- Doing a half batch was smart. The pasta would have taken way too long to make otherwise, and this was quite the gamble on a holiday.

Sometimes the experiments do work out… but only if you’re experienced enough to save them. I’m sharing this because it was cool, not because I think you should attempt. Don’t get yelled at for Thanksgiving okay? Stick to the recipe in my holiday cookbook. 😘🫶🏽

Another brainstorm for my journal today! I like doing these to give you an idea of how you can take familiar recipes in different directions or adapt to fit your event.

👩🏽‍🍳 For this menu, I wanted to feed a mixed crowd, adults & kids. The budget is not crazy tight, but I don’t want to overspend. Guests will be asked to contribute desserts, non-alcoholic drinks, and ice.

👩🏽‍🍳 Hibiscus tea (aka sorrel or zobo) is refreshing and festive for the holidays, serve in a large drink dispenser.

👩🏽‍🍳 Mulled wine is another crowd pleaser and easy to serve from a crockpot to stay warm. I’d use 2 bottles of wine, brandy, sugar, and aromatics such as orange, cloves, cinnamon sticks, and allspice.

👩🏽‍🍳 Suggested recipes:
- The collard greens soup recipe from my old blog was shared on Patreon today!
- Cornbread recipe is on Patreon or sage-cornbread recipe is in holiday ebook.
- Caramelized onion recipe and cranberry sauce in holiday ebook.
- Duck Fat Turkey Burgers recipe is on Patreon.
- Classic Mac & Cheese is on Patreon and gourmet version is in the holiday ebook.
- Buttermilk pie recipe is on Patreon as of today!
- Deep Dish Sweet Potato Pie recipe is in the holiday ebook.

👩🏽‍🍳 For setup, I recommend a dedicated counter, island, or table. Use a crockpot for the soup. Buy a disposable chafing dish set ($35-45 set of 3) for the other hot items. Buy sturdy paper bowls and plates, disposable utensils, etc.

👩🏽‍🍳 Make my all-purpose rub from the Volume 1 ebook and use it to season the greens, mac & cheese, and turkey burgers. Then adjust each recipe with the seasonings that weren’t included.

👩🏽‍🍳 The cranberry-pomegranate sauce from the Buttermilk Pie recipe on Patreon can also double as the sauce for the turkey burgers, if you only wanted to make one. 

👩🏽‍🍳 My Buttermilk pie or Deep Dish Sweet Potato Pie recipes are good candidates for slab pies. To do a traditional buttermilk crust rolled out, use all of the dough, which is typically for 2 crusts, to fit one half-sheet sized pan. Alternatively, do a graham cracker or saltine cracker crust.

📝 I’m testing the slab pie tomorrow and update if my recommendations change at all.

Thanksgiving 2022 throwback. Paced myself so I could shoot/document my work as I cooked. This was the culmination of about a month of duck-centric holiday shoots. For Turkey Day I kept it more traditional with smothered turkey wings but used duck in various forms for flavor throughout the menu. 

I’m proud of where I’m at today. My Thanksgiving journey started from a place of scarcity, back in my Florida apartment kitchen. That was where I cooked my first dinner in 2012, for my son. (He is now 20 and working in fine dining kitchens. 🥹) Raven is the same age as he was at the time of my first Thanksgiving blog post.

I had a lot of reasons to hustle back then. I’m grateful for this platform because it provided me with options to change my trajectory. (Never underestimate the power of a single mom who has been forced to figure shit out on her own. Shout out to us though. 💪🏾)

The goals are different every year. Cooking a full dinner made from scratch is a marathon, but I’d already done that many times over. Photographing it all was a bar I set a few years in, then publishing a holiday cookbook, and then it was hosting events or catering holiday dinners. Shooting a dinner from scratch on video was the culinary holy grail. So in 2022, I made *that* happen. (By myself.)

We had a whole day of holiday eating…starting with mocha cream pie for dessert. For appetizers, fried confit duck wings tossed in my harissa glaze + duck cracklin deviled duck eggs with saffron aioli. The smoked duck necks seasoned my stock and gravy for turkey wings. The dressing was made with homemade duck sage sausage, cornbread, brioche, apples, leeks. Mac & cheese with fresh pasta. Sweet potato casserole. Roasted garlic green beans. Smoked cranberry sauce from a previous cook.

Today’s #gumbo prep list! I’m making my smoked turkey and duck gumbo. You can find two different recipes for gumbo over on Patreon; one utilizes the pressure cooker to speed a few parts up. There’s also a Reel pinned to my page which shows the recipe steps for smoked turkey gumbo is detail. I usually do an oven roux because it’s safer and hands off (aka adhd-proof.)

It’s been awhile since I had the energy to manage the grill alongside a big project like this, and I am very happy to be back at it. Recovering from a sprained ankle at my big age was not fun lol. My day started with installing a quick replacement part. The #traegergrills customer service is easy - plus between 3 grills over several years, I’ve only needed a part once.

Remaining slides - some gumbo memories. My adventures started in 2017 when I decided to cook smoked turkey gumbo for the first time for 100 guests at my Friendsgiving event. We did that though!  Louisa and @cheftaulora will forever be my fave chef hires, @michellcclark came through as MC and all of the original DMV dinner party crew was in attendance. Back home I used to volunteer as guest chef at a retreat for wounded vets, and my duck gumbo was one of the menus for Christmas Eve one year.

In 2018, I travelled to NOLA to attend @howardconyers_phd Gumbo Jubilee with a group of Black culinary professionals. Saw a whole cow smoked. Met Leah Chase. (I still think about her fried chicken that day.) Met up with my college friend and my cousin @bettinajudd so it turned into a girls weekend. Ran into @wendellpcg on the street. Ate po’ boys at 4am.  Had oysters every day. 🔥

After that I continued to make gumbo an annual tradition, and sometimes more. My favorite pots have been the duck green gumbo and my smoked duck gumbo with oysters. Other than oysters, I don’t usually do seafood and meat mixed together anymore. But I would like to do an all-seafood gumbo next, with the lighter roux. I like it dark for duck. 🤤

#kitchenistadiaries

The kitchen can be a safe space to work it all out. Not enough credit given to the parts of the prep process which are therapy in the form of controlled rage. There’s a lot of that in holiday cooking, and a lot of reasons to need it. 

(Maybe they’re scared of the way our faces light up when we get to be honest about how it feels to crack bones and smash dough with the rolling pin.) 

🦆🦆🦆

Just things I thought about as I prepped this gumbo. I opted to break the duck down differently to keep the breasts whole. Butchery is fun, even if you’re not an expert. Just…cut it up. It’s all going into the same pot.

❤️‍🩹 I work through my feelings when it’s me-time, and then I am available to others when it is time to serve food. Honoring that duality has helped to make cooking feel less draining. 

❤️‍🩹 Future-me thinks I’d be good at facilitating the heavier conversations that come from our time in the kitchen. But right now, it’s still the season of healing and taking care of me.

Post-Thanksgiving #Gumbo. Smoked turkey thighs and duck, chicken andouille, okra, oysters. 

My friend said it was like a “warm hug from the inside” and I agree. A shared pot of something hot and slow-cooked, with skillet cornbread on the side, tends to be exactly the thing your soul was craving. It was a small but significant moment as we all paused to acknowledge the peace we felt. 

Cooking process was a combination of techniques from the two recipes on Patreon + needing to adapt on the fly. Oven roux. This time I did not take it all the way to a dark chocolate color because it would have over powered the chicken sausage and turkey. Landed just past peanut brown and it turned out perfectly. Cooked texmati rice in the duck stock and strained fat. Cornbreads on both nights were gluten-free and cooked w/ duck fat in a cast iron skillet. Second night I whisked some pumpkin puree into the buttermilk. 100% would do again. 🔥 That was our afternoon snack with a slice of smoked duck breast, cranberry sauce, and truffle honey.

First night gumbo was good; Next day gumbo was phenomenal. Mostly because I had time to let it reheat in the oven and concentrate the flavors. Will document this version…eventually. (Every pot is different, so gotta have some faith that the ancestors will guide you through the rest.)

I’m in need of a brief departure from holiday food after the last week so today’s grocery order will be for whatever I can throw together to make some tacos for the rest of the week. I’ll be in hiding until I recover from pretending to be extroverted for the last week. 😂

As a person that so many others look up to when it comes to cooking, it’s still difficult for me to share that I struggle to feed myself at times. But I know that I’m not alone, so I want to find ways to begin approaching this more in my content. 

I love my time in the kitchen and creating masterpieces, but on the other side of that is all the days I couldn’t find the energy to cook at all. In the last year, that’s been more than I can count. 

Periods of burnout and depression are inevitable for me and that is perhaps one of the most frustrating aspects of neurodivergence. It can happen at any time but is often triggered by stress. This time of year, the cold weather and extra work/social obligations come into play. Growth is planning for my toughest season rather than pretending “this winter will be different.” 

It’s layered with:
- Forgetting to eat
- Struggling to make a decision about what I want to eat (for hours sometimes)
- Fixating on safe foods / cravings
- Chronic pain and inflammation

Because I’m a mom and I live alone, we gotta eat regardless of how I am feeling. I don’t have unlimited funds to order out every day and that’s also literally the only reason why my solution isn’t just to hire a private chef. (I wish I could hire an energetic clone of myself. 🥴)

In these journals, just sharing some strategies that have worked for me. I do sometimes eventually get to the point of not being able to think about groceries, put them away, or cook, but goal is always to stay functional for as long as possible. Even *one day* out of the week for meal prep makes a difference in how I will be able to cope, in general. 

Routine is huge for me. The thing about establishing a routine is that even when life falls apart, you have something solid to come back to. You know where the baseline should be. I no longer see it as a failure on the weeks I didn’t prep. I’m just grateful I know what a “good” week looks like, and eventually I get back there.

If you’re trying to figure this out, be gentle with yourself. Everybody’s goals and strategies will look different. We are all working with unique challenges and privileges. 🫶🏽 #kitchenistadiaries

Recipe on Patreon! This soup featured a lot of my pantry faves and flavor bombs for easy cooking:
🥣 Hot Italian sausage which adds the seasoning and meat to the pot in one step.
🥣 Duck stock, or any kind of homemade poultry stock, means less time simmering because the flavor and nutrients are already there. It’s also a dramatically different mouthfeel compared to stock from a carton because of the natural gelatin.
🥣 Packaged gnocchi aka instant fluffy soup dumplings.
🥣 Lacinato kale, which wilts quickly while maintaining a nice texture; also works well from frozen.
🥣 Parmesan wedge, for extra umami in the broth.
🥣 Canned beans to thicken the broth.

With those ingredients in the pot, the work is done for you. Most of the prep was dicing fresh veggies, but tbh this soup could have relied on the homemade stock and be good enough.

A big pot of this with some crusty bread and I’m all set for a few days. 👍🏽

Had a good conversation with a friend today about growth and what it really looks in real time. (Spoiler alert: Slow.)

First slide is a page from my holiday journal. I did one for each year, but 2015 was a turning point. Three years after starting a food blog, I got my first camera and published my first ebook. Went right to shooting photos for the next ebook, which ended up being the Appetizers collection. Never used a real camera in my life but I figured out how to do just enough to create content.

At the time, I was unemployed and living at home with a toddler and preteen, had just lost my car. Started figuring out how to monetize my social media pages and deliver small catering orders. I got the call to cater for The Roots’ concert and remember taking an Uber from VA to MD to get there, somehow cooking and transporting all the food and equipment by myself. 

A few months later I had a gig out on the west coast. Took the kids with me for their spring break, but by the time we checked into the hotel in San Francisco I realized we were going to be stuck if I didn’t make a miracle happen. Finished the Appetizers ebook that night in the hotel and put it up for sale. Immediately my phone was pinging with notifications, and we were good for the trip and then some. 

(Later that year, I published The Kitchenista’s Holiday Recipe Collection. That was when I quit my last accounting job and never looked back.)

So many ups and downs in the years that passed. A lot of time spent wondering when things were going to move, what I was doing wrong? A lot of people who doubted my path, but many more who supported me. I came close to giving up more than once.

I finished that Appetizers ebook in a hotel I couldn’t afford to stay in. Seven years later, some of those original recipes will be executed by a hotel restaurant team for a Detroit holiday event. (Join me to celebrate!)

Sometimes the blessings are around the corner once you push past the discomfort of growth. Stepping into bigger projects, expanding your brand, none of that comes easily or quickly. I bet on myself and played the long game. 

It’s been a hell of a ride. 🔥 #kitchenistadiaries

These breakfast burritos offer a wallet-friendly solution for a laid-back weekend, a chaotic school day, working on the go, or even as a hangover cure. Once you realize how easy this is, you’ll want to keep a stash in the freezer at all times.

➡️ Recipe posted to Patreon for all tiers, along with reheating instructions for the microwave or air fryer. 

➡️ The ingredients are easy to find at most grocery stores. If you shop at Kroger, you can see what I grabbed in the recipe post.  For around $20, assuming you have butter/salt/hot sauce etc at home, this is a great deal. That’s only $2.50 per burrito!

Cleaned out the fridge for a quick lunch. Thawed a pork tenderloin the other day… almost forgot I needed to cook it so that’s what I needed to grab. Luckily pork tenderloin is easy to cook without a plan, but if you have time, season and air chill in the fridge for a few hours. 

I did salt/pepper/smoked paprika/mustard/poultry seasoning/cinnamon/hot truffle powder. Tossed in avocado oil first. 

Preheated heavy skillet med-high. Preheated oven or air fryer, 425°F.

Quick sear on all sides in the hot skillet, optionally add a pat of butter or some bacon fat - pork tenderloin is very lean.

Transfer to oven to finish cooking. I think it cooks more evenly on a cold pan vs the hot skillet but do what works for you. It will cook for 15-20 mins depending on size, spot check with a thermometer or use a probe to monitor more closely. 

Technically you can eat pork at 145°F (pink)which is how I like it when it’s a quality cut. I always ask whoever I’m serving, in this case a longer cook was preferred. I pulled it from the oven at 150°F and it probably went up a few degrees during the 5 minute rest. As long as you don’t go past 160°F you’re ok. Leftovers are good cold, sliced thin.

On the side… Used my skillet and the pork-butter to cook the last of my Holiday Hash from TJ’s. Butternut squash/sweet potato/onion/herbs etc. Reheated leftover roasted cabbage. Steamed green beans. Cranberry sauce.

Maybe it’s your inspiration for an easy holiday meal! Could also be turkey tenderloin instead of pork.

#kitchenistadiaries

Keeping these items on hand in the fridge and freezer has been a game changer for breakfast. Mornings are when I am least likely to have the time or desire to cook, but I’m rarely satisfied with cereal. In the last couple of years I’ve had a goal of not skipping breakfast, which works best when I have things I can reheat and/or assemble that still taste fresh. 

My staples include:

🥞 Pancakes - See my recipes for buttermilk pancakes, blueberry, sweet potato, or pumpkin. (You can sub gluten-free 1-for-1 flour if needed with same results!) 

🥣 Oatmeal - see my recipe for steel cut oats or sub rolled oats, both have a hearty texture and should be slow cooked with frequent stirring, similarly to grits. I usually just add a pinch of salt. On the side, I prep toppings like nuts, coconut, dried or fresh fruit, fruit compotes, honey/maple, etc. The oatmeal can also be used for a savory meal if desired.

🌯 Breakfast burritos - posted recipe for chorizo & egg burritos to Patreon. Includes tips on storage/reheating. You can also check out the Reel on my feed from this week.

🥚 Frittatas - posted about 3 ways to make these, over on Patreon today! Includes tips on storage/reheating.

🥤Smoothie packs - Easy to customize based on your favorite combinations. My recipe for green smoothies is on Patreon. So easy to grab a bag, dump into blender with your choice of liquid and supplements.

Adjust the ingredients to accommodate your dietary needs. Don’t overthink the cooking part. Simple recipes; the strategy is in storing small portions that can be easily reheated later.  Take an hour on the weekend to prep 1-2 recipes so you have some options in the fridge or freezer for the work week to choose from, and then build up a stash from there. For instance, I mostly get by with oatmeal prepped in the fridge for 3-4 days at a time and then I supplement with a smoothie here or there, a burrito for a weekend treat, etc.

Organizing a small kitchen is a challenge that I’ve grown to enjoy. I utilize my main two upper cabinet areas for pantry storage, with some carryover space in the basement. I have some ideas to add shelving upstairs, but for now I make it work. I like to be able to grab things while I am working and not have to interrupt the flow.

On one side - baking, pasta and grains, teas & coffee, nut butters and smoothie supplements, sweeteners, crunchy toppings. 

On the other side of the kitchen is my prep station for sauces, spices, microwave meals, canned goods, tinned seafood, broths and stock, pickled & briny things, tomatoes, noodles, chiles and curry, oils, and vinegars.

I re-organize by pulling everything out of the cabinets, sorting by type, then determining if containers or baskets make sense to group frequently accessed collections. I label with freezer tape or removable stickers, because this stuff changes often.  After everything is in its place I do a quick inventory and replenish staples.

Working through this winter kitchen prep list daily! My spice drawer is tore up, so that’s up soon because it drives me crazy. 😅

#kitchenistadiaries #pantrygoals #kitchenpantry #kitchenorganization

Epis: 🗣️ /eh-PEES/ (n.) Haitian seasoning blend, characterized by a harmonious combination of fresh herbs, vegetables, and spices. Typically used as a foundational element in Haitian cuisine, it is often used as a marinade or seasoning base, enhancing the taste of meats, stews, soups, and rice dishes.

Please see the free public post over on Patreon for the recipe. It includes my list of ingredients with quantities for what I usually add to epis, some optional differences, and storage tips. The texture will be chunkier in a food processor vs blender.

My best batch of epis over the years included culantro but I can rarely find it. I don’t care to sub cilantro if that’s the only option, just parsley. Same with scotch bonnet… if I have a fresh one, I’ll add it, but otherwise no heat. 

Patreon.com/kitchenista to read more!

And shout out to @cristaleyy for the introvert theme song of the season. 😅

#kitchenistadiaries #kitchenista #epis

🦆 Duck pho was the first project that comes to mind in my 2023 highlights. It was a pot that fed many - Sunday dinner with girlfriends, then a gift to send home with a friend who stopped by. On the third day, a solo feast for lunch. Two ducks broken down, bones simmered and skimmed for a light but flavorful stock seasoned with fish sauce, palm sugar, toasted spices, charred scallion and ginger. I didn’t stray too far from the authentic Vietnamese recipes in my research, and as I worked, I was filled with gratitude for the restaurants which deliver bowls of pho to my door. My biggest challenge was getting back to the kind of strenuous work in the kitchen that I hadn’t tackled for months prior to this, so for that I was proud of myself. 

The duck meat was plentiful - shredded leg and neck meat filled our first bowls, sliced duck breast in others. I added foie gras medallions to my last bowl, which melted into the broth for added richness. Mint, basil, cilantro, scallions, bean sprouts. Hoisin and chile sauces for dipping, a crunchy cucumber peanut salad on the side. I have some notes on the noodles for the next time I return here and thoughts on streamlining the duck stock process, but my first attempt was a success. No recipe to share, just a good memory. ❤️ #kitchenistadiaries

🥩 Dinner = steak sandwich night! My recipe notes are on Patreon.

I’ve made steak sandwiches this way for years and they always hit.  Hanger steak is my preferred choice in general, but especially for sandwiches. Cooked sous vide and sliced against the grain, it’s exceptionally tender with plenty of marbling. I season the steak with a simple coffee peppercorn rub that gets extra earthiness from mushroom powder. I snuck in some truffle powder here. When searing it, a pat of butter adds the final touch of richness, especially if you upgrade to a black truffle butter.

With a steak sandwich, it’s important that the slices of steak are manageable - not too thick, tough, or chewy - and not prone to sliding out of the sandwich. You want the toasted bread to have a pleasant crunch but yield to something soft yet substantial inside; ciabatta tends to be perfect for this. I make a quick spicy mayo with chili crisp or whatever hot sauce is on hand. Sautéed onions, spring greens or arugula, and a bright chimichurri sauce combine to add freshness and texture. In the summer I add sliced tomato. It’s like biting into a steak salad, and one of my favorite treats.

Journal prompt inspiration: What are your “food hugs” in the winter? These are things that give you the warm fuzzies, whether that’s felt in your belly, taste buds, mind, etc. For me, I crave a lot of soft, sticky, and creamy textures, crispy/crunchy contrast, nostalgic cozy vibes, warm broths and drinks, bright citrusy flavors, and so much more. It’s a running list that in no way stops at #14. 

Reasons I like making lists of winter cravings:
🫶🏽 grounds me to reflect on the positive things about the season
🫶🏽 gives me ideas for meals to cook that will improve my mood
🫶🏽 can sometimes be a starting point for exploring the specific “feeling” I’m after and figuring out a healthier way of achieving it with dietary modifications
🫶🏽 helps me identify what types of food I gravitate towards

What are your favorite food hugs this time of year? 

#kitchenistadiaries

A memorable food hug from 2023, inspired by a craving for chicken & dumplings with different ingredients on hand. I also wanted to challenge myself to work on my gluten-free recipes. Duck leg confit - duck legs that were cured and then slowly cooked in duck fat - stood in for shredded chicken. I already had jiggly duck stock for a nice rich broth. Cassava flour (made from manioc/yuca) worked well to achieve the very specific dumpling texture I was after. It also acted as a starch to thicken the duck broth. I plan to return to this idea over the winter to perfect the recipe process. 🥰

Meal prepping was the glue that held a difficult year together. I’m proud of myself for getting started. Today, I reflected on some of the lessons learned. Scroll through the other slides for some of the highlights!

The past few months have been about returning to my body, prioritizing my mental health, and establishing a reasonable work/life balance. With that came the need to quite literally get back to the basics of eating breakfast, lunch, and dinner. In all the years of cooking for others, I had not successfully managed this piece of my life at home. (I now understand that these challenges have a lot to do with neurodivergence, making meal prepping all the more important to figure out.) 

In my excitement to get back into it, I definitely overestimated the time I would be able to dedicate towards creating meal prep content. That shift will work itself out. For now, I share when I can but I am mostly focused on the work of actually implementing this in real time. My goal is to share the strategies and tools that are working for me rather than it all being about specific recipes or diet plans. I also don’t want to fall into the trap of content creation needing to be aesthetically pleasing, edited, etc. I just need to get my food cooked and be able to eat the right things, consistently.

(Knowing how to cook ≠ Knowing how to feed yourself.)

My journey would not have been possible without my friend @esme2428 so I also wanted to acknowledge her role as well! (Thank you! ❤️) Partnering with a friend has made the biggest difference in staying motivated, enabling us to share the workload, collaborate on ideas, and make the experience a fun time. Her parents also provided us with beautiful produce from their garden, which was a joy to cook.

This was my light. Looking forward to going harder in 2024. 🔥

🇭🇹 I made some #griot for the Haitian princess. She loved it, especially with the spicy #pikliz. Groceries required some adjustments but I think I got the flavors down!

- For the pork, I chopped up some pork belly and a few country pork ribs (which is really just pork shoulder.) The mix of textures worked well + pork belly creates a lot of fat on its own to braise the pork.
- Epis marinade was from the batch I prepped for the freezer last week, recipe on Patreon
- Pikliz is a spicy cabbage relish. I used red cabbage/carrot/onion/scallion/lime. I heated the vinegar to infuse the thyme and clove flavors faster, wilts the cabbage a bit. Trick I learned from making quick pickles, when you don’t want to wait 1-2 days.
- No fresh scotch bonnet pepper or even habanero, so my emergency backup is a scotch bonnet powder. It’s just as spicy and maybe even more so, but easy to add too much if you’re not careful.
- Plantains were yellow instead of green by the time I got to them, so on the sweeter side. This I didn’t mind because I like that contrast. But traditionally you would use unripe.
- On the side, brown rice + black beans that I cooked earlier in the week, seasoned with epis. Not from any kind of authentic recipe, just serving what I had.

I always enjoy learning how to cook foods from the Haitian culture so it can be part of my daughter’s education. That said… we’re down to be adopted by somebody’s auntie who can give her the real experience. 😂🙏🏽

#kitchenistadiaries

🇭🇹 On January 1st, we celebrated Haitian independence with Soup Joumou. This is a tradition that I enjoy sharing with my daughter so she can get a taste of her heritage. It’s also been a culinary exploration for me. Soup Joumou is a hearty pumpkin soup, often made with beef, root vegetables, cabbage, fresh herbs, seasonings, and served with pasta. The process to learn how to make it was humbling and transformative, feeling familiar only after several years of attempts.

This year was the second time making Soup Joumou with duck. I took my time with it, improving on the techniques from my first recipe test. My recipe journals this week detail the goals and challenges of making the recipe shine in the same way beef does. I wanted to present something that still captured the essence of authentic home cooking. Could I replicate the sensational mouthfeel of cow foot? Will I be able to adequately intensify the duck flavors while balancing the pumpkin? Would I conquer the holiday curse of rarely being able to capture a nice presentation on camera? Yes, yes, and yes - all wins. I achieved what I was after utilizing roasted duck stock with duck feet, cooking the meat separately as duck confit, and managing my time with restaurant-style prep.

Then I added fresh duck egg pasta, because I can’t help but show off… 😅

After I take a couple of days to bask in the glow of hibernation season, I’ll begin sharing my deep dives over on Patreon. Along with Joumou, I cooked up a few other Haitian specialties that I’m excited to tell you about! In 2024, I’m aiming for quality over quantity. More journaling, more time editing the detailed footage I record, and focusing only on projects I’m passionate about. 

Happy New Year! Thank you for joining me on this journey! 🫶🏽

#kitchenistadiaries #soupjoumou #jayzpastapairings #patreoncreator

Did you get your greens in for the new year? Preview of what I’ve been working on this week! Looking forward to sharing the full write-up over on Patreon this weekend… 

I’ve been exploring/learning/practicing recipes from and inspired by #Haitian cuisine. Before the holidays I tried griot (fried pork), banan peze (fried plantain) and pikliz (spicy cabbage condiment.) For the New Year, I did my Soup Joumou with duck. This week, I am using more of the same prepped ingredients and continuing my duck adventures.

🥬 Coconut milk roasted collard greens and kale -  You can get the original coconut milk greens recipe already posted over on Patreon. (Not a Haitian recipe, just one that worked with my meal.) The main difference here was palm oil and I used a Brazilian hot pepper. I love preparing my greens this way as it merges with so many of my dinner menus from the diaspora.

🦆Duck breast - marinated with epis before searing. The flavor on these was interesting because I marinated longer than usualy so it was more of a cure, and resulted in a texture that reminded me of a smoked pork chop.

🌶️ Sos Ti-Malice is a warm hot sauce. I make it differently every time depending on what I have to use but generally includes shallots, bell peppers, tomato paste, scotch bonnet or habanero, and (pikliz) vinegar. I incorporated some saffron habanero vinegar, roasted duck stock, and sour orange juice which was amazing with the duck breast.

🍚 Diri djondjon is rice made with liquid from steeped black djondjon mushrooms. This was my very first attempt and doing it blindly as I have never eaten it before. Ordered the mushrooms online! I was really in love with the flavors, deeply savory, but not happy with the rice texture which was completely on me lol. I was aiming for drier grains. So another round for that dish! Raven actually loved the softer rice and happily got seconds so it worked out. She liked the lima beans because we add those to jag (Cape Verdean rice.)

What should I try next? Have you been inspired to try any Haitian dishes?

Duck breast & Sos Ti-Malice. Round two! 

There was a lot going on at last attempt with the other dishes on my Haitian New Year’s menu. For recipe testing, ideally I focus on one thing at a time. In this case, getting the duck breast right. Did that! 🔥

Different type of duck breast - Magret, from a Moulard duck - bigger, red flesh and thick fat cap which I prefer for presentation, beefier flavor compared to the smaller Pekin duck breasts off the whole duck.

Already had my sauce and greens done from last round. Dialed back the rice - plain white this time - because the djon djon rice should be tested on its own. Took advantage of duck fat in the skillet and pan fried ripe plantain - great match to balance the spicy sauce.

Happy with results to write the duck and sauce recipe; my next steps would be to retest the rice dish and get that right before a final shoot with the full plated meal. Most likely I would wait until spring/summer when lighting is best, so that I can get photos on the same shoot.

Recipe development requires technical cooking and writing skills, time, patience, and a healthy appetite. It often involves heavy note-taking, research, and a lot of trial and error. Combine that with the parallel work of content creation, and it’s easy to see how many variables can change with each round of cooking.

Outside of commissioned recipe development, I do all of my work in real-time for our actual family meals. Everything I shoot and test is what we need to eat. Better for my budget and schedule, but can make for a long process to perfect complex dishes.

I use recipe journaling to document my steps, combined with video recording. I usually record everything even if the conditions aren’t ideal for edited content. It’s the easiest way to remember what I did, as sometimes it is months before I can return to a recipe.

When side dishes won’t need to be retested, I make extra on the first round to freeze and reheat for subsequent shoots so the plates look the same. 

Yes I do get tired of eating duck (sometimes) LOL! Once a week is good for me, I post about it more often than that though. 😂

A day in the life/kitchen. We made slow-roasted chicken seasoned with Moroccan spices, horseradish mashed potatoes, and prepped components for a Niçoise salad. In the evening I enjoyed some fresh oysters and bread with dinner.

My current fridge really excites me heading into the snowy weekend. I’m already thinking about leftover mashed potatoes as gnocchi…

My first thought this morning was to groan. Because it’s cold. Because bills were due. Because I could no longer put off tidying up my space. Because it was a meal prep day and I was starting off with a sink full of dishes and extra time on my feet. 

And then I remembered the work of focusing on gratitude. I found my music and my comfortable crocs, and I moved through the day with intention. Because the reward is opening the fridge and seeing the fruits of my labor - the evidence of my growth. When I am organized everything flows. The hard days still feel manageable.

Gratitude is remembering that I built this life. Specifically, this version of myself who is effectively running a home kitchen and making time to eat real meals. Since 2020, when working from home became a permanent thing and as such, I began to move differently so that my work and home life could coexist.

18-year-old me wouldn’t believe that meal prep is my time to socialize, or that I’m curating restaurant event menus instead of serving tables.

25-year-old me would be impressed that I figured out how to work from home with no rush hour traffic, high heels, or daycare late fees. 

30-year-old me would be proud to know that the recipes took me this far.

40-year-old-me would be happy that I kept going to find my peace. ❤️

#LimitingBeliefs can hold us back from experiences, growth, and enjoyment. In the kitchen, these can look like road blocks and hurdles on our cooking journey.

➡️ SWIPE for examples of some limiting beliefs you might hold as a home cook.

✍🏽 Today, I’m thinking about my own limiting beliefs. (The cool bonus to figuring your shit out in the kitchen is that you start applying the lessons in other areas of life.) Despite a strong start to the year, I had a frustrating week with school closures and snow. It was easy to get caught up in negative thought patterns. Fear of falling behind schedule with content, unexpected routine change, anxiety about outdoor maintenance, too much time consuming social media that wasn’t making me feel good about myself.

🙅🏽‍♀️ Challenging those thoughts looked like:
- Asking myself “Is it true / necessary / helpful?” “Am I okay?”
- Identifying root causes (guilt for resting & past trauma, not asking for help, poor planning, boredom, unrealistic comparisons)
- Actionable steps (rescheduling, eating prepped meals from the freezer, hiring snow removal, rearranging my living room to spark new decor ideas, gratitude meditations)

💫 My affirmation: I’m grateful for the opportunities the winter season offers to slow down, enjoy the scenery from the comfort of my home, and make time for hobbies outside of the kitchen.

🙋🏽‍♀️What is a limiting belief you face as a home cook? How do you challenge it?

If you saw me cook in my stories this weekend, thanks for the positive feedback. It helped confirm that this creation was one to share. Now run to Patreon and get the recipe. It’s live today! 💪🏾

I used up leftover mashed potatoes to make my gnocchi which worked great, but the sauce is what really stole the show. Savory, slightly spicy, earthy and luxurious in the way only #saffron can do. This was a gluten-free and dairy-free meal!

Recipe & additional notes: patreon.com/kitchenista 

The song is “Conversation Pit” by #Junetober. Conversation pits were a mid-century architectural feature with sunken space for seating within the home. I’m obsessed with the 90’s neo-soul and r&b group vibes that their album delivers. Instantly transported me back to a time when r&b was just different. You had to be there. 

This specific genre of music tricks me into cooking like I care about somebody. 😒🤣 Creatively, it works, so I embrace it. Maybe in Feb I will journal my way through uncomfortable feelings with a new playlist + recipes for 1. 😆

At any rate, YOU should make this for someone special. This is weeknight friendly with packaged gnocchi + adaptable for date-night or dinner parties with some care put into making homemade gnocchi.
